annote: B1875 .D38 Garber wants to replace the model of cartesian science as a geometrical science with something more complicated. The cause of seeking a replacement is that there is sufficiently strong evidence that Descartes endorsed, at some points, either a full blown HD method, or at least accepted some constraints to the claim that his science held the sort of certainty which was reserved for the mathematical sciences. This is due to the fact that he seems to accept that experiment are necessary for the construction of a science.Part of Garber’s argument is that "While we shall find a somewhat different situation when we examine the Principles, I shall maintain that in the works we are considering [pre-Principles], Descarte has neither adopted any hypothetical mode of argument, nor has he given up his plain for a certain science, and that, furthermore, this certain science is one in which experiment lays an indispensable role." (p.130).Garber believes that in the early writings Descartes treats the HD method as a method of presentation. That is, he belives that all his claims *can be* deduced in a purely geometrical manner, but for brevity and for the sake of not exposing his principles to the public, he chooses the method of hypothesis.Garber also holds that we should not understand DEscartes’ appeal to the method of hypothesis as a rejection of he goal of certainty. He notes that Descartes never explicitly asserts,even when asserting the many explanation are possible for a single phenomena, etc., that certainty is not possbile for the phenomena. Descartes can hold on to certainty by means of the crucial experiment.
title: Science and certainty in Descartes
Descartes, the aristotelians, and the revolution that did not happen in 1637

annote: QC6 .G25 1992Chap 9: God and the Grounds of the Laws of MotionGod concourse sustains the duration of created thing, this duration being merely a distinction of reason from their existence Pr I. 62. God’s continual sustenance is considered the efficient cause, but a causa secundum esse; a cause of being, while all efficient causes that are created things are causae secundom fieri. This view was borrowed from Aquinas summa.Duration: the quesiton of whether God conserves in partless atoms of time or in extended moments of duration is irrelevant, Garber argues. Both views can be resonably attributed to Descartes.The laws of nature are not“imposed" by Gods (as Leibniz’s God imposes laws), rather, they follows from the way God acts in the world (p.274). Garber also argues that since Descartes rejects substantial forms, he cannot endorse Aquinas’ picture of God as the primary cause of everything, but forms being the secondary causes responsible for sustanining particular thing. He writes that“What Descartes chooses in their place is God, who will act not only as the general conservator of the world, but as the direct cause of motion and change in that world (275).This picture may suggest the“cinematic view". That God causes motion by creating material bodies in different configurations. Garber suggests that this may have been Descartes’ view Le Monde and the Principles, but a different picture emerges in the letter to More (Aug. 1949). In order to understand this picture, we need to consider the picture that Descartes is trying to replace. The picture he is replacing is of substantial forms (Aquinas’ secondary causes) causing motions. How does motion come about in this picture? Garber holds that—according to Descartes—forms cause motion by being“modal cause", they can change the modes of bodies, but nothing more. God is a“substantial cause" because he can bring about the existence of the substance that have particular attributes and modes.But there is a problem from this view. What about Rest? Isn’t it equivalent to Rest? Garber’s answer involves appeal to the resistive force of rest. Seems tenuous.The derivation of the laws of motion starts with God’s constancy of action. Garber sees here evidence for the“divine shove" view, since on the cinematic view it is unclear why there should be motion at all. I can buy this....“What is important is that God, having created an impulsion that causes motion in bodies, sustains that impulsion, whether it be in hinm or in one of his creatures". The divine shove also explains why God sustains motion and not other numerical features of body (like number of triangles), since the creation of motion is unique.detailed discussion of how God’s immutability underwrites the laws. Interestingly, the laws of collision has a weird status, some of it is not justified, particularly the collision model on which it is based.Concerning force, Garber suggest the we reject Hatfield’s, Gueroult’s, and Gabbey’s position, in favor a force-as-epiphenomenal conception. Force is“nowhere" in Descartes’ universe, but merely a way to describe bodies that are moving in accordance to the laws of motion.

annote:
I shall argue that... Descartes profoundly transformed not only natural philosophy but mechanics as well, and that the new mechanical philosophy represented a rupture not only with Aristotelian natural philosophy but, in a way, with the science of mechanics as well. At the same time, I shall, it was the connection between mechanics and the new mechanical philosophy that allowed Descartes’ new science to remain intelligible to the adherents of the Aristotelian tradition he rejects and inteded to replace. p. 186.
What is a machine? Something that achieves human goals. Embedded in this conception of the domain of mechanics was a certain conception of the natural world, the distinction between the natural and the artificial, and a certain related conception of the relations between the science of physics and the science of mechanics (p.188).
Aquinas discusses the middle science in commentrary on De Trinitate q5a3ad6; In II Phys. lect. 3, n. 8; Summa Theol. 2–2.9.2 ad 3.
Descartes talk about mechanics in two senses: one is FOUNDATIONAL: mechanics becomes the epistemological route to the whole of physics, and the laws of physics are just the laws of mechanics. The other is NON-FOUNDATIONAL: mechanics is the fruit of a science of physics, and is a proper part of it. At the same time, when Descartes says that he is doing mechanics, it does not look like any 16th century text on mechanics. There are no simple machines. More importantly, there is no heaviness, which all previous mechanicians assume. When Descartes does Galilean style mechanics, he assumes heaviness, but is explicitly unhappy about it.
Importantly, Descartes does not believe machines have innate purposes. We imposed telos on machine, but in themselves they are just collections of parts. This is a departure from traditional mechanics, on which machines, artificial constructions, have purposes. Descartes brings the natural and artificial together by considering God as the creator of nature. But at the end of the day, the reference to God drops out, and natural items do not have purposes.
This is not a radical break with aristotelinism, since mechanics was thought to be compatible with aristotelian philosophy.
title: Descartes, mechanics, and the mechanical philosophy

abstract: Newton’s experiments into the resistance which fluids offer to moving bodies provide some insight into the way he related theory and experiment. His theory demonstrates a way of thought typical of 17th century physics and his experiments are simple enough to be replicated by present day students. Newton’s investigations using pendulums were discussed in a previous paper. In this paper Newton’s theory of the resisted motion of falling bodies is outlined, his investigations into the resistance offered to falling bodies by water and the experiments of others into the resistance offered by air are described and some implications for teaching about the nature of science are discussed.
title: Newton’s investigation of the resistance to moving bodies in continuous fluids and the nature of “frontier science”

abstract: This paper presents a detailed account of Descartes’ derivation of his second law of nature—the law of rectilinear motion—from a priori metaphysical principles. Unlike the other laws the proof of the second depends essentially on a metaphysical assumption about the temporal immediacy of God’s operation. Recent commentators (e.g., Des Chene and Garber) have not adequately ex- plained the precise role of this assumption in the proof and Descartes’ reason- ing has continued to seem somewhat arbitrary as a result. My account better reveals the dependence of the second law on fundamental principles about time and causality.
annote: The second law, unlike the other laws, depends on an assumption regarding the temporal immediacy of God’s operation, not just His immutability. By revealing this assumption, Gorham hopes to demonstrate "the unity of Descartes’ metaphysics and natural philosophy" (p. 433). The argument is that according to Garber and Des Chene, the argument for the second law appear in some ways arbitrary: by revealing its connection to premises about time and causality, Gorham shows that it is connected to metaphysical principles, as it is supposed to be.2. Proof of Rectilinear Motion: The seonc dlaw is that all motion is in itself rectilinear. According to Gorham, what this demands is thatall times a rectilinear “tendency”tendency (or inclination or action). Unlike actual motion, tendency is an instantaneous state of bodies which may or may not give rise to actual motion over time. This interpretation of Law II relies on a distinction between proper tendency and overall tendency. The overall tendency of a body will always be to continue in the actual path in which it continues: it is moving in a circle, its tendency is to move in a circle. However, its proper tendency is to move in a straight line, it is the tendency that is due to the body itself.But directionality is a feature of determination, not overall tendency. Gorham shows that determination can have instantaneous states. what the second law of nature more precisely postulates is that the determination of the proper tendency of each part of a moving body is always along a straight line.3. Gorham considers Des Chene and Garber on the proof.
title: The metaphysical roots of Cartesian physics: The law of rectilinear motion

title: Howard stein on Isaac Newton: Beyond hypotheses?

abstract: Newton’s methodology is significantly richer than the hypothetico‐deductive model. It is informed by a richer ideal of empirical success that requires not just accurate prediction but also accurate measurement of parameters by the predicted phenomena. It accepts theory‐mediated measurements and theoretical propositions as guides to research. All of these enrichments are exemplified in the classical response to Mercury’s perihelion problem. Contrary to Kuhn, Newton’s method endorses the radical transition from his theory to Einstein’s. The richer themes of Newton’s method are strikingly realized in a challenge to general relativity from a new problem posed by Mercury’s perihelion.
title: Newton’s methodology and mercury’s perihelion before and after einstein

abstract: In Philosophy and the Mirror of Nature (1979), Richard Rorty locates the perceived ills of modern philosophy in the “epistemological turn" of Descartes and Locke. Hatfield argues that Rorty’s accounts of Descartes’s and Locke’s philosophical work are seriously flawed. Rorty misunderstood the participation of early modern philosophers in the rise of modern science, and he misdescribed their examination of cognition as psychological rather than epistemological. His diagnostic efforts were thereby undermined, and he missed Descartes’s original conception of a general physics, and Locke’s probabilist analysis of the grounds for rational belief.

annote: The problem is why, if Descartes physics is deduced a priori from his metaphysics, does he appeal to empirical evidence, an a posteriori arguement, in order to defend it. First a comparison to Scholastics: in the scholastic tradition, metaphysics was distinguished from physics by the degree of abbstraction from ordinary experience. Metaphysics had nothing in particular to offer physics, since besides general concents (substance/accident, etc.), the physician had to study particular forms, forms that the metaphysician had no particular access to. Descartes is different from the scholastic on this count: he believes that metaphysics has something to teach the physicist. However, the particulars of his system are also different. He had made a ’housecleaning’ of the scholastic system, reducing the number of forms, possible explanations, etc. How does he defend this system?Descartes has 2 ways of defending his system: one a priori and one a posteriori. The a priori way is to claim that the substantial form of the scholastics are unintelligible on epistemological grounds. Hatfield writes:“the metaphysical justification of the fundamental principles of his physics depended upon a novel conception of metaphysical knowledge — one that bases such knowledge on pure rational intuition as opposed to abstraction from sensory particulars — as developmed in his Meditations on First Philosophy. p. 154. The a posteriori way was based on an “empirical”empirical criterion of explanatory adequacy.What is the motivation for each method of explanation? Hatfield notes that the“distinctive role of metaphysics, then, is to establish as certainly as possile what could be claimed as merely empirically plausible if left to its own, a poteriori, devices." p. 156. The two, then, work in tandem.Hatfield then stresses than according to a scholastic conception of science as demonstrative, this would not makes sense. He claims that Descartes aimed to change the very ideal of science in order to make his particular version of science more plausible.... Then a discussion about the circle of causes, effect, proof and demonstration and the way Descartes interpreted these terms.Useful introductory essay to these problem.

annote: To argue for the concurrentists position (that the action of secondary causes and god’s creating/conserving action are one and the same, without God being said to be the only cause) in light of the third meditation’s continual recreation passage. Concurrentism stands between occasionalism (which has god as the only cause) and full-blooded secondary causes.The second section–Historical background–is good on the relation of Eustachius to Raconis. It argues, following Ariew, that there existed a "scotist school" of Parisien philosophy that stood in contrast to a Jesuit "thomist" school. When D reads Scholastic texts to prepare for the Principia, he consults the Scotist school more than the Thomist.

abstract: Abstract This article responds to Professor Andrew Janiak’s recent attempt to defend the proposition that Isaac Newton did not believe in action at a distance between bodies (or any other kind of substance) (Janiak, 2013). His argument rests on a distinction between “three concepts of causation in Newton”, which leads him to conclude that although Newton did not believe in action at a distance between bodies, he was able to accept that gravity was a “distant action”. I critically examine Janiak’s arguments here, and the historical evidence he brings to bear upon it, and argue that Professor Janiak’s latest claims do nothing to undermine the view to which he is opposed, namely, that Newton did believe in the possibility of action at a distance between bodies.

title: Newton and action at a distance between bodies—a response to andrew janiak’s “three concepts of causation in Newton”

abstract: Euler’s ‘On the force of percussion and its true measure’, published in 1746, shows that not only had the issue of vis viva not been settled, but that the concepts of inertia and even force were still very much up for grabs. This paper details Euler’s treatment of the vis viva problem. Within those details we find differences between his physics and that of Newton, in particular the rejection of empty space and reduction of all forces to the operation of inertia through contact. One can further see how Euler’s philosophy of science embraced explanation through mechanisms and equilibrium conditions.

abstract: "A Catalogue of the Manuscripts of Christiaan Huygens inventories all known manuscripts written by Christiaan Huygens as well as all letters to or from him. Because almost all of the manuscripts are housed at the University of Leiden in a collection entitled Codices Hugeniani, the catalogue contains an inventory of that entire collection of family papers, including many involving Constantijn Huygens. In addition, because most scholars begin their research by consulting Oeuvres Complètes de Christiaan Huygens, which does not provide enough information to relocate the manuscripts edited therein, this catalogue essentially footnotes every edited piece by listing the source manuscripts page-by-page for each volume. Thus, the researcher should be able to move easily between manuscript and edition." –
annote: A Catalogue of the Manuscripts of Christiaan Huygens inventories all known manuscripts written by Christiaan Huygens as well as all letters to or from him. Because almost all of the manuscripts are housed at the University of Leiden in a collection entitled Codices Hugeniani, the catalogue contains an inventory of that entire collection of family papers, including many involving Constantijn Huygens. In addition, because most scholars begin their research by consulting Oeuvres Complètes de Christiaan Huygens, which does not provide enough information to relocate the manuscripts edited therein, this catalogue essentially footnotes every edited piece by listing the source manuscripts page-by-page for each volume. Thus, the researcher should be able to move easily between manuscript and edition."

abstract: In this paper, I argue that recent debates about Newton’s attitude toward action at a distance have been hampered by a lack of conceptual clarity. To clarify the metaphysical background of the debates, I distinguish three kinds of causes within Newton’s work: mechanical, dynamical, and substantial causes. This threefold distinction enables us to recognize that although Newton clearly regards gravity as an impressed force that operates across vast distances, he denies that this commitment requires him to think that some substance acts at a distance on another substance. (Dynamical causation is distinct from substantial causation.) Newton’s denial of substantial action at a distance may strike his interpreters as questionable, so I provide an argument to show that it is in fact acceptable.

abstract: In 1655, the philosopher Thomas Hobbes claimed he had solved the centuries-old problem of ’squaring of the circle’ (constructing a square equal in area to a given circle). With a scathing rebuttal to Hobbes’s claims, the mathematician John Wallis began one of the longest and most intense intellectual disputes of all time. ’Squaring the Circle’ is a detailed account of this controversy, from the core mathematics to the broader philosophical, political, and religious issues at stake.Hobbes believed that by recasting geometry in a materialist mold, he could solve any geometric problem and thereby demonstrate the power of his materialist metaphysics. Wallis, a prominent Presbyterian divine as well as an eminent mathematician, refuted Hobbes’s geometry as a means of discrediting his philosophy, which Wallis saw as a dangerous mix of atheism and pernicious political theory.Hobbes and Wallis’s ’battle of the books’ illuminates the intimate relationship between science and crucial seventeenth-century debates over the limits of sovereign power and the existence of God.
title: Squaring the circle: The war between Hobbes and wallis

title: Scientia in Hobbes

abstract: A remarkable thinker, Gottfried Leibniz made fundamental contributions not only to philosophy, but also to the development of modern mathematics and science. At the center of Leibniz’s philosophy stands his metaphysics, an ambitious attempt to discover the nature of reality through the use of unaided reason. This volume provides a systematic and comprehensive account of the full range of Leibniz’s thought, exploring the metaphysics in detail and showing its subtle and complex relationship to his views on logic, language, physics, and theology.

abstract: Denis Kambouchner Les Méditations métaphysiques de DescartesDenis Kambouchner, Les Méditations métaphysiques de Descartes, Presses Universitaires de France, 2005, 415pp, 19€ (pbk), ISBN 2130516254.Reviewed by Steven Nadler, University of Wisconsin-MadisonOne could easily be forgiven for thinking that we have more than enough books on Descartes’s Meditations, particularly those that take the meditation-by-meditation approach and walk us slowly through the theses and arguments of the work. And yet, with his new book, the first in a projected series of three volumes and devoted primarily to the First Meditation, Denis Kambouchner adds a significant new study to this most-studied of early modern philosophical treatises.Kambouchner takes his time in approaching the text itself and the particular arguments of the First Meditation. Rather, the first half of the book is devoted to discussion of more general themes, including the historical and philosophical context of the Meditations. Kambouchner looks closely at questions related to the work’s substance and style, and considers its purpose, its method, and its audience. He examines the development of the meditation form as devotional testimony and literary technique, and provides a subtle reading of the way in which Descartes employs that form for his own philosophical purposes. He notes the differences and the similarities with antecedents in Augustine and Anselm (with whose spiritual exercises Kambouchner assimilates, to some degree, Descartes’s first-person "analytic" – as opposed to "synthetic" – undertaking) and other religious authors. He also, in these opening chapters, lays out a persuasive case for the unity of the Meditations and the Objections/Replies, showing how both are equally essential elements in the presentation of Descartes’s metaphysical project, albeit without undermining the independence of the text of the six meditations itself.Above all, Kambouchner’s "Introduction Générale" offers an insightful reconstruction of the context of metaphysics in the pre-Cartesian world and examines the various and often competing senses of ’metaphysics’ employed therein (science of being, science of God, etc.). Kambouchner wants to persuade us that, rather than thinking in terms of a "Cartesian revolution" in philosophy, we should look at Descartes as offering a "reinvention of metaphysics", one that can be understood only in the light of late medieval developments. This, he insists, somewhat paradoxically but with perfect justification, will give us a better sense of Descartes’s originality. Suarez is an important character in this story, for, according to Kambouchner, it was he who simplified and generalized metaphysics into the study of "being insofar as it is real being", including among its objects infinite being, that is, God, and thus making theology a subset of metaphysical inquiry.For Descartes, in Kambouchner’s view, metaphysics is not the science of being qua being, but rather the accomplishment of a particular foundational task through the methodical treatment of certain immaterial and thus metaphysical objects (especially God and the human soul, including the principles of knowledge). In this regard, there is no distinction, for Descartes, between metaphysics and first philosophy. To the question so often asked by recent French scholars, "Is Descartes truly a metaphysician?" or "Does Descartes belong to the history of metaphysics?", Kambouchner answers with a definite ’yes’, but not by showing how Descartes is doing metaphysics in the Scholastic sense of the term. "La métaphysique de Descartes pourra donc bien n’être pas de la meme espèce que celle de l’École . . . mais si l’on convient d’appeler ’métaphysique’ la demarche d’un esprit qui sait atteindre, comme dira Leibniz, au "fond des choses", ou du moins constituer un tel fond, et traiter de chaque chose à partir de ce fond, il [sera] ridicule de disputer à Descartes la qualité de métaphysicien" (90).One of the more interesting of these early chapters is the one in which Kambouchner investigates the objet or purpose of the Meditations, and here he goes beyond the perfunctory treatment usually accorded this question in similar books. He takes seriously the apologetic nature of the work with respect to the proofs of God’s existence and the immortality of the soul (whereby Descartes’s target is the libertine or atheist). "La contribution des Méditations à la ’cause de la Religion’ est-elle donc chose qu’il faut renoncer à prendre au sérieux? Nullement . . . [A]ux yeux de Descartes, aucun lecteur attentive de ces Méditations ne pourra manquer d’acquérir de l’existence de Dieu et de l’immortalité de nôtre âme une très parfaite certitude" (74). He also examines with great care the work’s function in providing epistemological and ontological foundations for Cartesian mechanistic science (whereby the target is the Scholastic professor wedded to the Aristotelian system). As for whether or not one of Descartes’s targets is also the skeptic, as has been often claimed (most notably by Popkin and Curley), here Kambouchner is himself a bit more skeptical. He argues that, rather than the Pyrrhonian, the more likely opponent here, because he represents a greater danger to Descartes’s scientific program, is the probablistic empiricist (such as Gassendi).Of course, the real work in any book such as this comes with the analysis of the meditations themselves. Kambouchner succeeds here beautifully. He does a fine job in his examination of the First Meditation of providing both the basic explanations needed for enlightening the novice and the more complex inquiries expected by the seasoned specialist. He begins by offering a defense of Descartes against the charge that he misconstrues the nature and structure of human knowledge, and also provides a plausible justification for Descartes’s use of the method of doubt. In his thorough consideration of this method, Kambouchner looks at the process or experience of doubting itself, the obstacles to be overcome (e.g., the force of habit in our everyday beliefs) and the means of overcoming them, and the nature of the doubt ultimately engendered by the method (contrasting it, for example, with the state of epokhé pursued by ancient skepticism). Kambouchner is especially good in these sections at bringing to our attention certain tensions, inconsistencies, and problems in Descartes’s text(s) and in proposing plausible resolutions for them. He is interested in, among other things, the perennial question of whether or not the reasons for doubt are (to cite Descartes himself) "hyperbolic and ridiculous" or "very strong and quite considerable", as well as in the issues of who exactly the meditator is supposed to be and whether all of the principles subjected to the method of doubt in the First Meditation are intended to be empirical ones, grounded in either the naïve or critical use of the senses.Finally, Kambouchner turns to the particular arguments of the First Meditation, those intended to instill in the meditator the epistemological doubts from which the cogito and the existence of God are to provide the fulcrum for his rescue. Kambouchner generally adopts a careful, level-headed approach. He is sensitive to the variety of texts that must be used when offering a deep interpretation of the Meditations (the Rules for the Direction of the Mind, the Discourse on Method, the Search After Truth, the "Conversations with Burman", etc.) and to the different ways in which they must be brought into play. He also tends to avoid extremes in his interpretations, and does not have any obvious axes to grind.Two elements of this part of his book are especially noteworthy. First, Kambouchner offers a very sensible answer to the question of the relationship between the deceiving God argument and the doctrine of the creation of the eternal truths. He takes exception to a common scholarly tendency to closely link the two. He grants that they have between them "un air de famille" that makes a "rapprochement" inevitable – indeed, they both derive from a recognition of God’s omnipotence. But this should not lull us into overlooking crucial differences between them, what Kambouchner calls an "opposition diamétral qui est aussi une essentielle dissymétrie" (327). In essence, not only is it the case that one doctrine has God creating truths while the hypothesis of "Dieu trompeur" has God creating falsehoods, but the power of the "Dieu trompeur" is something we can basically grasp, if not fully comprehend, while the notion of God’s power to make it not be the case that 2+2=4 "envelloppera un paradoxe insupportable".Second, Kambouchner addresses the relationship between the hypothesis of "Dieu trompeur" and the fiction of the "malin génie", the evil deceiver. Here, too, Kambouchner resists a simple identification of the two. These possible sources of deception not only work in different ways, he insists, but they represent very different kinds of relationship to some powerful being. Kambouchner argues, first, that the power of the evil deceiver should not, despite appearances, be confused with the omnipotence of God. He then claims that because the deceiving God is depicted as the creative source of our being, hence of our systematically unreliable faculties, such a divinity would be much more remote from us than an evil deceiver who, on Kambouchner’s reading, is intimately involved in causing our particular illusions, being the instigator of our non-veridical experience or representations of things. Above all, he concludes, an all-powerful but deceiving God is, in fact, something incomprehensible, a self-defeating hypothesis (as Descartes hopes to show in his subsequent proof that God cannot be a deceiver), whereas the evil deceiver is, while hyperbolic, still quite conceivable, particularly since this deceiver runs up against the limits of my will insofar as he cannot actually force me to believe anything.There is something missing from Kambouchner’s discussion here, however. He recognizes that, on at least one occasion, in the conversation with Burman, Descartes says that the evil deceiver has created him ("me creavit"). So why should there necessarily be these differences of mechanics and of proximity or intimacy between the two hypotheses? Perhaps the evil deceiver argument does indeed work in the same way as the "Dieu trompeur" argument works: the deceiver has maliciously created me with faulty faculties. On this reading, the evil deceiver hypothesis is substituted for the deceiving God hypothesis only to avoid attributing (incoherently and impiously) such malice to God. Kambouchner seems to be aware of this possibility of assimilating the two hypotheses, suggested by Descartes’s remarks to Burman (365), but he does not address it seriously.One of the virtues of this book, all too rarely found in the French literature on Descartes, is a real engagement with English-language scholarship. This is, without question, one of the best books on the Meditations to appear in a long time. It is certainly the finest, and most thorough, treatment that the First Meditation has received since Harry Frankfurt’s Demons, Dreamers and Madmen (which was, incidentally, as far as I know, the first study of Descartes by an Anglo-American philosopher to be translated into French). The three-volume work should, when completed, become one of those magisterial studies (like Gueroult’s two-volume masterpiece, Descartes selon l’ordre des raisons) that is standard reading for generations. I am very much looking forward to the next two installments.
title: Les méditations métaphysiques de Descartes: Introduction générale, première méditation

abstract: A striking feature of Newton’s thought is the very broad reach of his empiricism, potentially extending even to immaterial substances, including God, minds, and should one exist, a non-perceiving immaterial medium. Yet Newton is also drawn to certain metaphysical principles—most notably the principle that matter cannot act where it is not—and this second, rationalist feature of his thought is most pronounced in his struggle to discover “gravity’s cause”. The causal problem remains vexing, for he neither invokes primary causation, nor accepts action at a distance by locating active powers in matter. To the extent that he is drawn to metaphysical principles, then, the causal problem is that of discovering some non-perceiving immaterial medium. Yet Newton’s thought has a third striking feature, one with roots in the other two: he allows that substances of different kinds might simultaneously occupy the very same region of space. I elicit the implications of these three features. For Newton to insist upon all three would transform the causal question about gravity into an insoluble problem about apportioning active powers. More seriously, it would undermine his means of individuating substances, provoking what I call “Newton’s Substance Counting Problem”.
annote: I shall argue, it would not be possible for Newton to resolve the causal problem about gravity as he conceives it while insisting upon all three elements. To do so would transform the question about gravity’s causal means of operation into an insoluble problem about apportioning active principles or powers. More seriously, it would undermine his means of individuating substances, provoking what I shall call “Newton’s Substance Counting Problem”.

abstract: Although Newton carefully eschews questions about gravity’s causal basis in the published Principia, the original version of his masterwork’s third book contains some intriguing causal language. “These forces,” he writes, “arise from the universal nature of matter.” Such remarks seem to assert knowledge of gravity’s cause, even that matter is capable of robust and distant action. Some commentators defend that interpretation of the text—a text whose proper interpretation is important since Newton’s reasons for suppressing it strongly suggest that he continued to endorse its ideas. This article argues that the surface appearance of Newton’s causal language is deceptive. What does Newton intend with his causal language if not a full causal hypothesis? His remarks actually indicate a way of considering the force mathematically, something he contrasts to the structure of the force as it really is in nature. In explaining that, he identifies a significant disjunction between the physical force itself and mathematical ways of considering it, and the text’s significance lies in its view of the force’s structure and in the questions raised about the relationship between mathematical representations and the physical world.

annote: Describes the changing scope of mechanics in relation to the then-current categories of scientific knowledge, from the perspective of commentaries of the Questiones.Questiones. Traditions of the Questiones and Jordanus, Archimedean Statics, and one of Pappus and Hero, Center of Gravity approach.Mechanics in the Middle AgesMechanics in the Middle AgesMechanics in the Middle Ages. Problems of motion were treated in natural philosophy, along with proportion theory and intention and remission. Topics associated with the balance and lever were part of the science of weight, itself a part of mathematics. The science was based on the work of Jordanus of Nemore, less on Archimedes. And simple machines were considered within the practical, mechanical arts. However, the availability of QuestionesQuestiones in the 16th century prompts a renegotiation of these boundaries. “commentators took great care to distinguish this new science of mechanics from practical mechanics on the one hand and from natural philosophy of the other (p.45)”commentators took great care to distinguish this new science of mechanics from practical mechanics on the one hand and from natural philosophy of the other (p.45).Characteristics of Sixteenth-Century MechanicsCharacteristics of Sixteenth-Century MechanicsCharacteristics of Sixteenth-Century Mechanics Four characteristics distinguished mechanics from other sciences. 1. It was theoretical rather than manual. 2. it was mathematical, although its subject was natural. 3. it considered motion and effects against nature. 4. it produced motion for human ends. Before the translation of the QuestionesQuestiones it was unclear how to interpret Aristotle’s comments regarding mechanics, so commentators did not consider it on par with Optics, Harmonics, and Astronomy, but rather as some sort of engineering art the precise nature of which was unknown. “One of the effects of the reintroduction of the Mechanical Problems... was to elevate mechanics to the status of a theoretical, intermediate science and to apply to it the theory of subalternation elaborated in the Middle Ages and still actively discussed in the sixteenth century (p.47)”One of the effects of the reintroduction of the Mechanical ProblemsMechanical Problems... was to elevate mechanics to the status of a theoretical, intermediate science and to apply to it the theory of subalternation elaborated in the Middle Ages and still actively discussed in the sixteenth century (p.47).Commentators on the Mechanical Problems: Humanist PhilosophersCommentators on the Mechanical Problems: Humanist PhilosophersCommentators on the Mechanical Problems: Humanist Philosophers The interest of the humanists was more philological and philosophical than mathematical. Niccoló Leonico TomeoNiccoló Leonico Tomeo The first Latin translation was made by the Venetian humanist Vittore Fausto (1580–1551?) and published in 1517, although supplanted by Tomeo’s 1525 translation (also in Venice, 1456-1531). Tomeo merely repeats the characterization of mechanics given in the first few paragraphs of the QuestionesQuestiones. Alessando Piccolomini (1508–1579)Alessando Piccolomini (1508–1579) extensive commentary equated mechanics to optics and harmonics in terms of subalternation. Nevertheless, he held on to the idea that mechanics concerns acts against nature. Mathematical Practitioners: Niccolo Tartaglia (1499–1557)Mathematical Practitioners: Niccolo Tartaglia (1499–1557). Unlike the humanists, the math practitioners were aware of the mathematical works of Pappus, Hero, Archimedes, and Jordanus. Tartaglia considered the science of weights the theoretical part of mechanics, and a predominantly mathematical science. Physical arguments were not to be used at all; only confirmatory observations were allowed. “Tartaglia could thus assert the superiority of mathematical arguments over physical arguments and then explain their different conclusions as the result of material hindrances”Tartaglia could thus assert the superiority of mathematical arguments over physical arguments and then explain their different conclusions as the result of material hindrances. He used the term “subalternate science”subalternate science. However, he did not attempt to reconcile Archimedean and Jordanian proofs, siding mostly with the Jordanian (and QuestionesQuestiones) reliance of virtual velocities, not Archimedean equilibrium.

annote: Lennox cites this essay with great approval. The study is based on PhysicsPhysics 2.2 and MetaphysicsMetaphysics M3. Thesis: Aristotle has a genuine philosophy of mathematics that does not collapse into Platonism. Although this is also (Muel70?)’s intent, Lear holds that Mueller mistakingly falls into the common conception that for Aristotle physical bodies do not perfectly instantiated mathematical properties. Lear holds that this mistake leads to the psuedo-Platonic dillema: if mathematical knowledge if true of things that cannot obtain in the physical world, what is it true of?The discussion begins with analysis of the argument against Mathematical Platonism. Aristotle’s position is such that various substances can be considered in different aspects: so man can be considered as indivisible, and planet can be considered as moving, etc. In relation to magnitudes, Lear writes:The theory [of alternating proportions] is about spatial magnitudes and numbers, only not as spatial magnitude or number, but rather as magnitude [simplicitersimpliciter]; that is, they exhibit a common property, and they are being considered solely in respect of thisLear dubs this with-respect-ness as the introduction of a quaqua-operator, and puts things is spiffy logical form. The argument is that in MetaphysicsMetaphysics M.3 Aristotle hold that the distinction between necessary and incidental properties can only be considered in light of the quaqua operator, i.e., under a certain description of a substance. The standard interpretation is that essential predicates are those that make the substance what it is. In M.3, the distinction can only be made under a description (i.e., b as an F), even if the described property (F) may be essential to b’s being the substance that it is.Why does this not lead to falsity? Lear has a discussion that makes a mountain our of a mole-hill. His point is merely that any positing of a seperable object as existant is as a useful fiction, not as an independently existing substance.This interpretation rests on the assumption that Aristotle thought that physical objects really do instantiate geomtrical properties. Two passages suggest a contrary thesis. In MetaphysicsMetaphysics B.2 (the tangent to the bronze sphere) and K.1 ... I need to re-read section II.Section III deals with the difference between geometry and arithmatic.
title: Aristotle’s philosophy of mathematics

abstract: Isaac Newtonâ€™s views on the mindâ€“body relation are of interest not only because of their somewhat unique departure from popular early modern conceptions of mind and its relation to body, but also because of their connections with other aspects of Newtonâ€™s thought. In this paper I argue that (1) Newton accepted an interesting sort of mindâ€“body monism, one which defies neat categorization, but which clearly departs from Cartesian substance dualism, and (2) Newton took the power by which we move our bodies by thought alone to be a member of the family of forces that includes gravity and electricity. Time and again, Newton draws an analogy between the ultimate cause and nature of the volitional powers of mind and the ultimate cause and nature of these other forces.

abstract: This paper focuses on the developments experienced by natural philosophy and mathematics in Bologna during a period of rapid change in the relationship of the various disciplines in the faculty of Arts and Medicine. Insisting that university science was characterized by a greater vitality than the traditional historiography usually concedes, this examination first offers some comments about the place of natural philosophy in the Italian universities, then discusses more specifically the University of Bologna. Changes that took place in the funding of natural philosophy, in the designation of astronomy and mathematics, and in the cycle of books read for natural science are all examined in turn and are complemented by a series of tables.
annote: Good quotes on the nature of Renaissance Universities, and the flux of natural philosophy and mathematics. "In Italy as elsewhere, natural philosophy was one of the three standard philosophical branches (natural philosophy, moral philosophy, and metaphysics) studies i nthe universities. p.132 Bottom of p.134 notes that Jesuits criticized universities for their lack of a graduated curriculum. This sort of criticism would suggest that Jesuit institutions kept to the Ratio strictly – after all, they took it as a point of pride that they reformed the chaotic curriculum of the standard university.Lines also makes clear, with lots of references to Grendler (2002), that Astronomy was taught as a branch of mathematics. I can use this fact as justification that when Descartes, etc. thinks of "mathematics" they also think of mixed mathematics."The rolls suggest a rigid separation between mathematics and natural philosophy in Renaissance university teaching. Although there are some examples of individuals who taught both astrology and physics in Bologna during the 14th century, I know of no teacher there who taught both natural philosophy and mathematics during the 15th and 16th centuryes. The reasons commonly offered for this kind of arrangement are well known: that medieval science was inherently indifferent or opposed to experimentation, since philosophers were more preoccupied with the unchanging principles of nature than with measuring and observing its phenomena. However, none of this explain why the relationship between the two fields seem to be more visible during the 13th and 14th centuries... [some evidence for increased experimentation].... One explanation for the dissociation one can observe between natural philosophy and mathematics may be the increasing specialization taking place within philosophy itself.

abstract: Alessandro Piccolomini and several other prominent 16th-century Aristotelians claimed that while a sphere touches a plane at a point in geometry, a material sphere touches a plane not at a point but over a small surface. These thinkers thereby called into question the reliability of geometric reasoning in physics. In this article I provide a detailed analysis of Galileo’s reply to such worries about geometry in the Second Day of his Dialogue Concerning the Two Chief World Systems. Because his infamous extrusion argument relies on the premise that a sphere touches a plane at a point, Galileo takes the opportunity to defend the argument and to attack geometry’s critics. According to the account I propose, Galileo argues for the applicability of geometry to physics by defending the legitimacy of geometric approximations and by advocating an expansive notion of geometric curve.

annote: Work in the mixed science tradition beginning with pseudo-Euclid and Archimedes is an instance of the theory of science of the Posterior Analytics. The crux of the theory is that 1) a subordinate science depends on the superior for its proofs and principles, 2) the subordinate science treates knowledge of the fact, the superior of the reasoned fact, 3) subordinate sciences are perceptual, superior are mathematical. McKirahan analyses the examples of optics/geometry and harmonics/arithmatics and question cases of triple suordinate sciences, such as arithmatics/mathematical harmonics/acoustical harmonics. The division corresponds to something like pure, applied, and experimental science, although McKirahan doesn’t use this language. He then analyses the 3 theses in relation to each pair in the triple, concluding that they only hold with respect to certain pairs and with certain qualifications. The argument seems mostly right. The main problem seems to me that“fact gathering" is difficult to fit into the subordinate science. Open avenues of investigation should be whether Aristotle on fact gathering provides further evidence, and whether a moden conception of experimental sciences can help out Aristotle. However, a careful study with lots of references. Oh, McKirahan self-consciouly mirror Zabarella’s treatment of the mixed sciences!! Following Zabarella, he introduces a nice turn of phrase to indicate a form of treatment (i.e., geometrical treatment): modus considerandi.

abstract: This paper contends that the first argument of Hume’s "Of scepticism with regard to reason" entails that humans have no knowledge as Hume understands knowledge. In defending this claim, we also see how Hume’s argument anticipates an important aspect of an extremely influential 20th century development: the collapse of the analytic/synthetic distinction.
title: Hume on knowledge, certainty and probability: Anticipating the disintegration of the analytic/synthetic divide?
title-short: Hume on knowledge, certainty and probability

abstract: "Spinoza’s Theological-Political Treatise was published anonymously in 1670 and immediately provoked huge debate. Its main goal was to claim that the freedom of philosophizing can be allowed in a free republic and that it cannot be abolished without also destroying the peace and piety of that republic. Spinoza criticizes the traditional claims of revelation and offers a social contract theory in which he praises democracy as the most natural form of government. This new Critical Guide presents new essays by well-known scholars in the field and covers a broad range of topics, including the political theory and the metaphysics of the work, religious toleration, the reception of the text by other early modern philosophers, and the relation of the text to Jewish thought. It offers valuable new perspectives on this important and influential work"–

abstract: Abstract  Over the last few years a resurgence of Newtonian studies has led to a deeper understanding of several aspects of his Philosophiae naturalis principia mathematica. Besides the new translation of Newton’s masterpiece, these contributions touched on his mathematical style, investigative method, experimental endeavors, and conceptual systematization of key notions in mechanics and the science of motion (I. Newton, The “Principia”. A new translation by I. Bernard Cohen and Anne Whitman assisted by Julia Budenz (Berkeley: University of California Press, 1999), hereafter New translation. Readers can find a useful bibliography on Newton in I.B. Cohen and G. Smith, eds, The Cambridge Companion to Newton (Cambridge: Cambridge University Press, 2002, hereafter Cambridge Companion), 465–80.). With regard to the last topic, recent works have identified two notions where Newton’s choices look unclear and scholarly opinion is divided. These notions are materiae vis insita or vis inertiae, namely the inherent force of matter or force of inertia, and vis centrifuga or centrifugal force. It is my conviction that the two notions became inter-related in Newton’s thought starting from the time of composition of the Principia and that a new look at them will simultaneously clarify matters about both. Newton’s beliefs about the nature of centrifugal force did not affect his calculations of planetary and cometary orbits in the Principia, but they are none the less of considerable intellectual interest. After a brief introduction on Huygens and the early Newton, Sect. 2 focuses on Newton’s views in the Principia and its preliminary manuscripts. Section 3 presents a summarized account of Leibniz’s views, which are necessary for understanding Newton’s criticism of them. This is the subject of Sect. 4, where we find his views most fully spelled out.

Aristotle on geometrical objects

annote: There is a prima facie sense in which geometrical proposition are not about universals (i.e., about something’s being a triangle), but about triangles directrly (i.e., about a mathematical object). “This sense of ’to be about’ can perhaps be paragraphsed as ‘to presuppose as existing’.(And) Although there is a tendency for individuals to hold analogous view about universals and mathematical objects, there is no necessary connection betwen the issues.” Muller takes for granted that mathematics is about universals for the commentators, but cautions that they are not clear about the distinction between universals and mathematical objects. Follow a discussion of several commentators, including Alexander, Ammonius, Philoponus, Proclus, Simplicius. The basic idea is that Aristotle’s first interpreters read him as an “abtractionist” (which Mueller think is wrong?), but later commentators, inspired by Platonic and Pythagorean idea start to hold a “Projectionist” position on mathematics. First page of article has nice 4 option on how to read aristotle on mathematical objects.

annote: Two positions exist regarding Descartes’ derivation of the laws of motion. First, that the laws of motion are fully establishbed by the essence of God, perhaps in a logically rigorous sense. This means that both their content and truth is grounded in God. Second, that God’s essence only determines the general features of such laws, setting constraints without determining any particular set (Williams). Nadler’s position in that, in the Principles, Descartes believes that God’s essence uniquely determines the content of laws of motion, although this is not a rigorous processes of logical entailment. The confirmation of the laws as the“true" laws is based on empirical evidence. In Le Monde, the situation is tighter and more akin to to logical entailment.On p. 366, Nadler links the laws with God’s attributes, but claims that this is an“interpretive reconstruction". In the text itself, Descartes is not very explicit or clear on just what stepts the arguments involve. This is what lead Bernard Williams to conclude that Descartes does not think that the laws of“determinately deducible from the nature of God." In fact, Nadler does not see a necessary connection between the god’s immutability and the *particular* law of conservation found in the principles.Section 2 is a reconstruction of the deduction of the laws, focusing on the ontological ground of the laws.Section 3 is a reconstruction of the epistemological basis of the laws. The evidence for Nadler’s positive view is given here.Section 4 concerns the counter-arguments. The end of the section (378ff) is the heart of the argument and appeals to evidence from Le Monde about Descartes’ general philosophy of science.Nadler ultimately appeals to the distinction between "explaining" and "proving" which Descartes mentions in both Le Monde and in letter to Morin.

abstract: ABSTRACT Over the last two decades a new scholarship on alchemy has emerged, leading to a fundamental reformulation of knowledge about alchemists and their activities. We now know that medieval and early modern alchemists employed experiment in concert with theory to demonstrate the existence of stable “chymical atoms,” which were thought to combine with one another according to a hierarchical theory of matter. Employing laboratory-based analysis and synthesis, alchemists were among the first explicitly to enunciate the principle of mass balance and to show that materials are compounded of the ingredients into which they can be physically decomposed. Perhaps even more surprisingly, these convictions and practices arose out of the interaction of alchemical practice with scholastic Aristotelianism, long viewed by historians of the Scientific Revolution as antithetical to experiment. Thus the new historiography challenges both a long-standing marginalization of alchemy itself and a commonplace view of Aristotelianism as inimical to the early modern growth of experimental science.
title: What have we learned from the recent historiography of alchemy?

abstract: Newton’s ’Principia’ was the crowning achievement of 17th Century Natural Philosophy, bringing together the works of great thinkers like Galileo and Johanes Kepler. This great work supplied the momentum for the Scientific Revolution and dominated physics for over 200 years. Although it was later demonstrated to have limitations at the atomic level, the principles of Newtonian physics are still applicable to much of our everyday lives. The casual reader may find this book difficult to work through, however. Newton’s three laws of motion are not stated in the language that is used in modern introductory physics texts. A good companion to this book is ’Feynman’s Lost Lecture’ in which Richard Feyman demonstrates planetary motion using the same geometric techniques employed by Isaac Newton, but in a more clear, modern style.

abstract: Ronald Numbers has recruited the leading scholars in this new history of science to puncture the myths, from Galileo’s incarceration to Darwin’s deathbed conversion to Einstein’s belief in a personal God who "didn’t play dice with the universe." The picture of science and religion at each other’s throats persists in mainstream media and scholarly journals, but each chapter in Galileo Goes to Jail shows how much we have to gain by seeing beyond the myths. –from publisher description

annote: The purpose of the article is to show that Aristotle’s wheel is a “transformation machine”transformation machine placed between theories of matter and theories of motion. It is also meant to show the relations between the continuum physicumcontinuum physicum and the continuum mathematicumcontinuum mathematicum in Galileo’s and Gassendi’s thought.The problem of the rolling sphere was used to motivate nominalist theories of the continuum in the middle ages. The issues was the following: if a circle touches a line at a point, a rolling circle will trace out a collection of points, not an Aristotelian continuum. I take it the conflict is that the line is supposed to be infinitely divisible, and in this case it is made from a collection of finite quantities. As an answer, Periera and Piccolomini, e.g., held that mathematical points had no physical reality. The nominalist solution was to deny the reality even of the mathematical point, and to hold the existence of finite although unimaginably small magnitudes. The problem is mentioned in Algazel, Chatoon, Gerard of Odo, Crathorn and Harclay, Buridan, Burley, Wodeham, Alnwick, Avicenna, and Maimonides.The evolution in Galileo’s thought regarding atomism is detailed. Initially, he considers physical atoms extended and holds that mathematical reasoning must be distinguished from physical reasoning! Nice quotes. Palmerino holds the opinion changes in order for Galileo to answer “two question concerning the behavior of material bodies and also to provide an implicit justification for one of the fundamental principles of his theory of fall”two question concerning the behavior of material bodies and also to provide an implicit justification for one of the fundamental principles of his theory of fall. The two problem are cohesion and rarefaction/condensation (which in the previous page she blames Shea for noting because those are “clearly cited by Galileo”clearly cited by Galileo). Regarding these, the characterization of the difference between solid and liquids, which impinges on the notion of resolution and composition seems doubtful. Look carefully, especially at the context of quotes, which are disembodied. The principles for the theory of fall are that space, time, and motion are composed of extensionless indivisibles. The principle is the continuity of motion and time. The argument here is based on a single passage, which is not particularly clear itself.After the single passage, Palmerino returns to an analysis of the mathematics/physics distinction and cites passages from the DialogueDialogue in whic the bronze sphere and Salviati’s counter argument are discussed. The passages and interesting, they show that Galileo did not conviece of material embodiment as a corruption. Mathematics can describe material entitiesmaterial entities perfectly!! Palmerino argued against Feldhay, who considers Galileo’s argument simplistic, that it is not. Or rather, she just states that.

abstract: This article analyzes the evolution of Mersenne’s views concerning the validity of Galileo’s theory of acceleration. After publishing, in 1634, a treatise designed to present empirical evidence in favor of Galileo’s odd-number law, Mersenne developed over the years the feeling that only the elaboration of a physical proof could provide sufficient confirmation of its validity. In the present article, I try to show that at the center of Mersenne’s worries stood Galileo’s assumption that a falling body had to pass in its acceleration through infinite degrees of speed. His extensive discussions with, or his reading of, Descartes, Gassendi, Baliani, Fabri, Cazre, Deschamps, Le Tenneur, Huygens, and Torricelli led Mersenne to believe that the hypothesis of a passage through infinite degrees of speed was incompatible with any mechanistic explanation of free fall.
title: Infinite degrees of speed: Marin mersenne and the debate over galileo’s law of free fall

annote: Euclid’s fifth book defines “equimultiple”equimultiple proportionality for any magnitudes whatsoever, and “rational”rational proportionality for rational quantities (number, for Euclid). Euclid never shows that the rational prop. is deducible for equimultiple prop, of vice versa. Clavious provided this equivalence in his commentary on the ElementsElements (1574). Galileo believes that equimultiple proportionality was “obscure”obscure and provided a new definition in 1641, dicating the tract to Toricelli. Galileo shows that his definition is equivalent to equimultiple prop. Paolo argues that Galileo’s tract echoes Calvius, in formal detail, orientation, and intent. The paper also show “some of the difficulties encountered by Galileo in applying the equimultiple technique outside of the domain of pure mathematics, and which may eventually have led [Galileo] to seek an alternative to Euclid’s equimultple proportionality. §1 Clavius held that ratios of rational quantities, since they can always be reduced to rations of numbers (Element X), wear their “similarity”similarity on their sleeve, so, since proportionality is defined in terms of similarity between rations, he went back to this notion to try to shed light on the equimultiple definition. He held that Euclid framed the equimultiple definition in order to show that proportions of irrational quantities show that same fundamental characteristic of rational proportions. Clavius proof in complicated because numbers are non-continuous quantities and rations of numbers are not fraction in the modern sense. This means that manipulations of rations can only be carried out within the framework of properties available in the arithmetical books of the ElementsElements (which aren’t too rich) (p.572).§about Galileo’s definition. Galileo’s tract starts by noting that if we are to understand the “nature”nature of proportional magnitudes, we need to pick one of their properties... Galileo’s definition seems no more obvious that Euclid’s and Paolo believes that Galileo worked backwards from Clavius’ model to arrive at his general property (Clavius just showed equivalence, he did not reduce both types of proportion to a single property).Galileo’s definition of proportionality, Paolo argues, must be understood visually. Galileo is not simply assuming that a unique proportionality exist (and Guisti claims), but “sweeping away the difficult task of actually having to construct magnitudes that are proportional according to his new definition and replacing this task with a visual aid (p.584)”sweeping away the difficult task of actually having to construct magnitudes that are proportional according to his new definition and replacing this task with a visual aid (p.584). In other words, instead of the rigor of proving existence by finding the right ratio, he simply provides a diagram that makes obvious that such a ratio exists. “In other words, Galileo seems to be transferring the idea of proportional numbers – in the sense of Euclidean arithmetical proportionality – into the domain of continuous magnitudes, which have the added bonus of being easier to manipulate visually than integers (p. 584).

title: The obscurity of equimultiples: Clavius’ and galileo’s foundational studies of euclid’s theory of proportions

annote: How did Galileo mathematize nature? We need to pay attention to the form of his mathematics in order to answer this. In particular, we need to pay attention to the “mental models”mental models underlying his use of Euclidean proportions as the language of early mathematized physics. The core insight is that some of Galileo’s reasoning is not expresible in the language of Euclidean proportions, thus it must be expressible as a “mental model”mental model. §2 on mental models and their use in history, with the aim in showing that they are not necessarily ahistorical. Models are generalized images: they are isomorphic to the situations they represent, but can represent abstract elements that cannot be imagined and classes of physically realizeable situations. Models can be both kinematics and dynamic. §3 on the visual dimension of Galileo’s proportional reasoning. Being with the postulate underlying the 1588 theorems on the centers of gravity. There are two undefined notions: similarity and “being in the same ratio”being in the same ratio i.e., proportionality. Galileo exlicitly accept the equimultiple definition of proportionality, but allow similarity, which for him implies proportionality, to be determined visually.Euclid first proved that equiangular triangles have proportional sides and then deduced their similarity, whereas Galileo first recognised within his mental model the similarity of configurations of weights and then conjectured the proportionality of their arms... Galileo’s postulate is to all intents and purposes tantamount to a conjecture on the very nature of proportional magnitudes, ofr a clear reason. Galileo has no proof that equimultiple proportionality can be successfully applied to the case of his balances. Therefore, he is claiming that proportionalities can be generated on only be directly pplying the equimultiple technique but also by means of... the construction of visually similar configurations of physica magnitudes... Thus, Galileo’s mental model of similar balances succeeds in rendering homogeneous the world of Euclidean proportionality and the world of physical quantities. (p.242)In §5, Paolo speculates that Galileo borrowed the balance model from Pappus, who uses it to analyze the potentiapotentia required to move a sphere down an inclined plane. Pappus (republished by Commandino in 1588 and 1602), saw a balance “within”within the inclined plane case, and Paolo suggests Galileo does the same within his proof of Archimedes’ law in DiscosiDiscosi and MecanicheMecaniche, seeing a balance “within”within a cylinder in equilibrium. Another good quote:I have suggested that some aspects of Galileo’s mathematization were cognitively dependent on non-symbolic mental models. The deduction toolkit of Euclid’s theory of proportions simply furnished the symbolic structure of Galileo’s mathematization. Indeed, it was the use of mental models that provided the innovation allowing Galileo to breakthrough the barrier of Euclidean and Archimedean traditions. (p.254)In §6 Paolo argues that mental models explain modes of Galileo’s argumentation to which the category of “thought experiments”thought experiments does no justice.

abstract: ABSTRACT Alchemy now holds an important place in the history of science. Its current status contrasts with its former exile as a “pseudoscience” or worse and results from several rehabilitative steps carried out by scholars who made closer, less programmatic, and more innovative studies of the documentary sources. Interestingly, alchemy’s outcast status was created in the eighteenth century and perpetuated thereafter in part for strategic and polemical reasons—and not only on account of a lack of historical understanding. Alchemy’s return to the fold of the history of science highlights important features about the development of science and our changing understanding of it.

abstract: The widely accepted supposition that Newton’s De gravitatione was written in 1684/5 just before composing the Principia is examined. The basis for this determination has serious difficulties starting with the failure to examine the numerical estimates for the resistance of aether. The estimated range is not nearly nil as claimed but comparable with air at or near the earth’s surface. Moreover, the evidence provided most likely stems from experiments by Boyle, Hooke, and others in the 1660s and does not use evidence available in the late 1684. The document supports Newton’s contention that the aether medium incorporates very large voids thereby proving that body and space differ but does by no means completely reject its corporeal nature or eliminate its resistance. Newton’s use of the term inertia provides no conclusive evidence for a late date as often claimed and his definition of gravitas is difficult to reconcile with a late one.

annote: Hobbes’s fondness for geometry does not entail its sufficiency for all scientific inquiry, As is usually supposed. Instead, Geometrical method, "logistica," is unique among his means of knowing. Although it conforms to pronouncements common to all inquiry, It also combines analytic and synthetic reasoning in peculiar ways. His definitive formulation is here retrieved from near-Oblivion, And its stipulations are discussed in detail. It follows from these that no other science is derivable from mathematics, According to his scheme. Only civil philosophy, Because modeled after geometry, Is able to attain a like exactitude and certainty.
container-title: Journal of the History of Philosophy
title: Hobbes: The art of the geometricians

abstract: Hobbes’ philosophy of geometry was eccentric to contemporary movements and worsted in specific controversy. But he laid down stipulations defining geometry and its method which might provide a significant and workable alternative "meta-geometry". Some of these are isolated and reinterpreted here, especially those concerned with describing magnitudes, motions and quantities, and with his use of proportions. Rather than refutation of commentaries and historical rehash, the effort here is to isolate definitive texts and to offer a reinterpretation of their arguments in succinct form showing their coherence and their interdependence with his other philosophic principles.
title: Hobbes: Geometrical objects

The Formation of Descartes’s Mathematical Thought – Ch. 1. Descartes and Jesuit Mathematical Education – Ch. 2. The Mathematical Thought of Christoph Clavius – Ch. 3. The First Attempt at Reforming Mathematics – Ch. 4. The Mathematical Background of the Regulae ad Directionem Ingenii – Ch. 5. The Concept of ’Mathesis Universalis’ in Historical Perspective – Ch. 6. ’Universal Mathematics’ in Aristotle – Ch. 7. ’Mathesis Universalis’ in the Sixteenth Century – Ch. 8. ’Mathesis Universalis’ in the Seventeenth Century – Conclusion: Descartes and the Modern Scheme of Learning. BOOK JACKET: Covering both the history of mathematics and of philosophy, Descartes’s Mathematical Thought reconstructs the intellectual career of Descartes most comprehensively and originally in a global perspective including the history of early modern China and Japan. Especially, it shows what the concept of“mathesis universalis" meant before and during the period of Descartes, and how it influenced the young Descartes. In fact, it was the most fundamental mathematical discipline during the seventeenth century, and for Descartes a key notion which may have lead to his novel mathematics of algebraic analysis."–BOOK JACKET.
title: Descartes’s mathematical thought

abstract: It is widely accepted that the notion of an inertial frame is central to Newtonian mechanics and that the correct space-time structure underlying Newton’s methods in Principia is neo-Newtonian or Galilean space-time. I argue to the contrary that inertial frames are not needed in Newton’s theory of motion, and that the right space-time structure for Newton’s Principia requires the notion of parallelism of spatial directions at different times and nothing more.
