The lectures focus on Aquinas’s integration of Augustinian and Aristotelian modes of enquiry, the inability of the encyclopaedists’ standpoint to withstand Thomistic or genealogical criticism, and the problems confronting the contemporary post-Nietzschean genealogist. MacIntyre concludes by considering the implications for education in universities and colleges.
title: Three rival versions of moral enquiry: Encyclopaedia, genealogy, and tradition
title-short: Three rival versions of moral enquiry

abstract: Thorough and lucid survey of Western philosophy from pre-Socratics to mid 20th century ‚Äî major figures, currents, trends. Valuable section on contemporary philosophy ‚Äî Brentano, Ortega, Heidegger, others. ’Brevity and clarity of exposition...’ ‚Äî ’Ethics’.
title: History of philosophy

abstract: I have mixed opinions about this. Some topics are covered well, some pictures are nice (even though they are painted in orange and shades of black), and the History sections are interesting to read to take a break from learning multivariable calculus. Also this book contains some material typically not found in a standard calc text (e.g. Stewart). But that’s where the good stuff ends. Some topics are covered in extremely little detail, for example section on polar coordinates has one trivial example, which is common sense. However that section fails to show a better, more rigorous example of integration using them. I was unfortunate enough to have this as a textbook for my Advanced Calculus class. My frustration got to the point where I just borrowed a copy of Stewart from my friend and studied from it, because reading Marsden’s book was simply not as productive and efficient. Let’s compare this to a Multivariable Calculus (5th edition) by Stewart: Stewart’s book has much better, colored pictures. Better paper also. Smaller in physical size. Better examples.If you are stuck with this book in your course, then try to get a copy of Stewart or Salas as a supplement. Trust me on this one.
title: St guide t/a vector cal 3e: midlife

abstract: The pendulum is a universal topic in primary and secondary schools, but its full potential for learning about physics, the nature of science, and the relationships between science, mathematics, technology, society and culture is seldom realised. Contributions to this 32-chapter anthology deal with the science, history, methodology and pedagogy of pendulum motion. There is ample material for the richer and more cross-disciplinary treatment of the pendulum from elementary school to high school, and through to advanced university classes. Scientists will value the studies on the physics of the pendulum; historians will appreciate the detailed treatment of Galileo, Huygens, Newton and Foucault¬ís pendulum investigations; psychologists and educators will learn from the papers on Piaget; teachers will welcome the many contributions to pendulum pedagogy. All readers will come away with a new awareness of the importance of the pendulum in the foundation and development of modern science; and for its centrality in so many facets of society and culture.
title: The pendulum: Scientific, historical, philosophical and educational perspectives
Medieval philosophy

abstract: Of what nature is the mind? So Colin McGinn starts his first chapter, and this is his guiding question. He pursues the answer with a boldness and provocativeness rarely encountered in philosophical writing. As he explains, my aim has been to give the reader something definite and stimulating to think about, rather than to present a cautious and disinterested survey of the state of the subject. The Character of Mind provides a general introduction to the philosophy of mind, covering all the main topics: the mindbody problem, the nature of acquaintance, the relation between thought and language, agency, the self. In particular, Colin McGinn addresses the issue of consciousness, and the difficulty of combining the two very different perspectives on the mind that arise from introspection and from the observation of other people. His aim throughout is to identify the recalcitrant problems clearly, and to suggest fruitful approaches to their solutions, always avoiding facile answers. The second edition of this classic book adds three completely new chapters on consciousness, mental content, and cognitive science, bringing it abreast of current developments. A distinctive viewpoint is adopted, stressing consciousness, but the intention is still to come to grips with the underlying philosophical problems, accessibly articulating the deep difficulties we face in theorizing about the mind. From the reviews of the first edition: “a very good introduction to the philosophy of mind. . . . written with confidence and authority . . . a fine text for an undergraduate course.” Jonathan Lear, The Times Literary Supplement “a lucid and impressive discussion . . . to be recommended to students and professionals alike . . . brilliant book.” Brian O’Shaughnessy, London Review of Books “clear, stimulating and thought-provoking.” Bernard Harrison, Philosophy “an impressive piece of worktough, elegant, ingenious, argumentative and controversial.” Nicholas Everitt, Times Higher Educational Supplement
title: The character of mind: An introduction to the philosophy of mind
Problems in philosophy: The limits of inquiry

abstract: Werner Heisenberg’s Copenhagen interpretation of modern quantum theory has long been the majority view. It includes two theses: 1) the wave/particle duality thesis that wave and particle are two manifestations of one and the same entity, and 2) the scientific realism thesis that the theory is literally descriptive of microphysical reality.This book’s editors, Cushing (a physicist) and a Reverend McMullin (a philosopher), both members of the University of Notre Dame faculty, dissent from the majority view. Cushing rejects the Copenhagen interpretation, and the Reverend McMullin rejects the realist thesis.In 1935 Einstein, Podolsky and Rosen (’EPR’) proposed a hypothetical experiment to demonstrate the present quantum theory’s incompleteness by showing that it implies action at a distance, which the three co-authors (EPR) viewed as absurd.In 1964 Bell published his locality inequality, and in 1982 Aspect, Dalibard, and Roger implemented the actual EPR experiment with an outcome that corroborated the Copenhagen interpretation by violating Bell’s inequality.Based on their articles in this book I see the Reverend McMullin as clearly the junior partner of the two editors of this book. The Reverend’s contribution is typical of his other writings - merely a recitation of some well-known pre-twentieth-century history, in this case about the idea of action at a distance.Quine once quipped that people take up philosophy either because they like philosophy or because they like history. Quine is clearly among the former, and I place the Reverend McMullin among the latter.Some of the articles are reprints, but two original works are those by the physicists Teller and Howard. They postulate ’holism.’ But holism means little to physicists except as a name for what has already been described by their experimental findings and physical theory.I believe that it is better just to let the theory speak for itself in its own terms, and to accept it as a literal and realistic description. Such scientific realism is what Quine calls ’ontological relativity.’The book’s title notwithstanding the historic philosophical consequences of quantum theory have not been discussed in this book. They are the emergence of the contemporary pragmatist philosophy of language and of science, which include the thesis of ontological relativity. The two editors seem to me to bring a nineteenth-century philosophy to quantum theory.Google my book titled History of Twentieth-Century Philosophy of Science at my web site philsci with free downloads by chapter.Thomas J. Hickey
title: Philosophical consequences of quantum theory: Reflections on bell’s theory

abstract: Prepared by nine distinguished philosophers and historians of science, this thoughtful reader represents a cooperative effort to provide an introduction to the philosophy of science focused on cultivating an understanding of both the workings of science and its historical and social context. Selections range from discussions of topics in general methodology to a sampling of foundational problems in various physical, biological, behavioral, and social sciences. Each chapter contains a list of suggested readings and study questions.

author.given: Clark Glymour James Lennox Peter Machamer J. E. Mcguire John D. Norton Wesley C. Salmon Kenneth F. Schaffner

title: Introduction to the philosophy of science

abstract: This practical, easy-to-use guide provides answers to the most common problems encountered by students in the writing of history research papers. It employs a practical approach beginning with the first task, selecting a topic, and takes the student through how to prepare a bibliography–without becoming bogged down in the nature and philosophy of history. Included are three student exercises designed to improve techniques in locating library resources, using historical criticism, and preparing footnotes.
title: Selections from the essays of montaigne

abstract: Covering the general fields of mathematics, astronomy, mathematical geography, physics, chemistry and chemical technology, geology and meteorology, biology, medicine, and physiological psychology, the present collection surveys the field of Greek scientific achievement over a thousand-year period. Many Greek scientific treatises were written and read by cultivated people who did not regard themselves as specialists. These works should appeal today to those readers who wish to understand not only the foundations of modern science, but also a vital element of the humanistic tradition.
title: A source book in greek science

abstract: History and fate of the universe. Speculations on the big questions of modern cosmology. Extends theoretical frontiers and offers opportunities to grasp the significance of current theories.
title: Theories of the universe

abstract: Evil threatens human reason, for it challenges our hope that the world makes sense. For eighteenth-century Europeans, the Lisbon earthquake was manifest evil. Today we view evil as a matter of human cruelty, and Auschwitz as its extreme incarnation. Examining our understanding of evil from the Inquisition to contemporary terrorism, Susan Neiman explores who we have become in the three centuries that separate us from the early Enlightenment. In the process, she rewrites the history of modern thought and points philosophy back to the questions that originally animated it. Whether expressed in theological or secular terms, evil poses a problem about the world’s intelligibility. It confronts philosophy with fundamental questions: Can there be meaning in a world where innocents suffer? Can belief in divine power or human progress survive a cataloging of evil? Is evil profound or banal? Neiman argues that these questions impelled modern philosophy. Traditional philosophers from Leibniz to Hegel sought to defend the Creator of a world containing evil. Inevitably, their efforts–combined with those of more literary figures like Pope, Voltaire, and the Marquis de Sade–eroded belief in God’s benevolence, power, and relevance, until Nietzsche claimed He had been murdered. They also yielded the distinction between natural and moral evil that we now take for granted. Neiman turns to consider philosophy’s response to the Holocaust as a final moral evil, concluding that two basic stances run through modern thought. One, from Rousseau to Arendt, insists that morality demands we make evil intelligible. The other, from Voltaire to Adorno, insists that morality demands that we don’t. Beautifully written and thoroughly engaging, this book tells the history of modern philosophy as an attempt to come to terms with evil. It reintroduces philosophy to anyone interested in questions of life and death, good and evil, suffering and sense.
title: Evil in modern thought: An alternative history of philosophy

abstract: Here, in a new edition, is Nelson Goodman’s provocative philosophical classic–a book that, according to Science, ’raised a storm of controversy’ when it was first published in 1954, and one that remains on the front lines of philosophical debate. How is it that we feel confident in generalizing from experience in some ways but not in others? How ore generalizations that ore warranted to be distinguished from those that are not? Goodman shows that these questions resist formal solution and his demonstration has been taken by nativists like Chomsky and Fodor as proof that neither scientific induction nor ordinary learning can proceed without an a ’priori’, or innate, ordering of hypotheses. In his new foreword to this edition, Hilary Putnam forcefully rejects these nativist claims. The controversy surrounding these unsolved problems is as relevant to the psychology of cognitive development as it is to the philosophy of science. No serious student of either discipline can afford to misunderstand Goodman’s classic argument.
title: Fact, fiction, and forecast, fourth edition

abstract: Nietzsche is not fed up with christianity, he is fed up with christians, and the people who distort christianity. Nietzsche is not the antichrist, he is simply the Messenger in a greek tragedy. We are the antichrist.’In reality there has been ofnly one christian, and he died on the cross. The Evangel died on the cross. what was called ’Evangel’ from that moment on was already the oposite of what he had lived’antichrist 39Five stars for Nietzsche, three for the lack of notes. Also, there are many times when Nietzsche writes in french or latin and there is no note or translation.ps I’m older than twelve.
title: The twilight of the idols and the anti-christ: Or how to philosophize with a hammer
title-short: The twilight of the idols and the anti-christ

abstract: A collection of critical essays edited by Harry G. Frankfurt. This Anthology has been specially prepared for Anchor Books and has never before appeared in book form
title: Leibniz a collection of critical essays edited by harry g. frankfurt

abstract: Metaphor and Thought reflects the surge of interest in and research into the nature and function of metaphor in language and thought. Philosophers, psychologists, linguists, and educators raise serious questions about the viability of the traditional distinction between the literal and the metaphorical, discussing problems ranging from the definition of metaphor to its role in language acquistion, learning, scientific thinking, and the creation of social policy. In the second edition, the contributors have updated their original essays to reflect changes in their fields. The volume also includes six new chapters that present important and influential new ideas about metaphor that have appeared in such fields as the philosophy of language and the philosophy of science, linguistics, cognitive and clinical psychology, education, and artificial intelligence. The book will serve as an excellent graduate-level textbook in cognitive psychology, linguistics, and artificial intelligence.
title: Metaphor & thought

abstract: All the writings of Plato generally considered to be authentic are here presented in the only complete one-volume Plato available in English. The editors set out to choose the contents of this collected edition from the work of the best British and American translators of the last 100 years, ranging from Jowett (1871) to scholars of the present day. The volume contains prefatory notes to each dialogue, by Edith Hamilton; an introductory essay on Plato’s philosophy and writings, by Huntington Cairns; and a comprehensive index which seeks, by means of cross references, to assist the reader with the philosophical vocabulary of the different translators.
title: The collected dialogues of plato: Including the letters

abstract: Nontechnical essays on hypothesis in physical theory, concept of number, magnitude, force, intuition vs. logic, more. Chapters include ’On the Nature of Mathematical Reasoning,’ ’Mathematical Magnitude and Experiment,’ ’Non-Euclidean Geometries,’ ’Space and Geometry,’ ’Experiment and Geometry,’ The Classical Mechanics,’ ’Energy and Thermo-Dynamics,’ ’Hypotheses in Physics,’ and ’The Calculus of Probabilities.’
title: Science and hypothesis

abstract: Professor Hilary Putnam has been one of the most influential and sharply original of recent American philosophers in a whole range of fields. His most important published work is collected here, together with several new and substantial studies, in two volumes. The first deals with the philosophy of mathematics and of science and the nature of philosophical and scientific enquiry; the second deals with the philosophy of language and mind. Volume one is now issued in a new edition, including an essay on the philosophy of logic first published in 1971.
title: Mathematics, matter and method

abstract: Professor Hilary Putnam has been one of the most influential and sharply original of recent American philosophers in a whole range of fields. His most important published work is collected here, together with several new and substantial studies, in two volumes. The first deals with the philosophy of mathematics and of science and the nature of philosophical and scientific enquiry; the second deals with the philosophy of language and mind. Volume one is now issued in a new edition, including an essay on the philosophy of logic first published in 1971.
title: Mind, language and reality

abstract: This is the third volume of Hilary Putnam‚Äôs philosophical papers, published in paperback for the first time. The volume contains his major essays from 1975 to 1982, which reveal a large shift in emphasis in the ‚Äòrealist‚Äô¬†position developed in his earlier work. While not renouncing those views, Professor Putnam has continued to explore their epistemological consequences and conceptual history. He now, crucially, sees theories of truth and of meaning that derive from a firm notion of reference as inadequate.
title: Realism and reason

abstract: ’The Linguistic Turn’ provides a rich and representative introduction to the entire historical and doctrinal range of the linguistic philosophy movement. In two retrospective essays titled ’Ten Years After’ and ’Twenty-Five Years After,’ Rorty shows how his book was shaped by the time in which it was written and traces the directions philosophical study has taken since.’All too rarely an anthology is put together that reflects imagination, command, and comprehensiveness. Rorty’s collection is just such a book.’–’Review of Metaphysics’Richard Rorty is University Professor of Humanities at the University of Virginia.
title: The linguistic turn: Essays in philosophical method
Engaging science: How to understand its practices philosophically
The spirit of modern philosophy
Explanation

abstract: ’On Metaphor’, a collection of fourteen essays by eminent philosophers, literary critics, theologians, art historians, and psychologists, illustrates and explores a striking phenomenon in modern intellectual history: the transformation of metaphor from a specialized concern of rhetoricians and literary critics to a central concept in the study of human understanding. These lively and provocative essays probe the nature, function, and meaning of metaphor and collectively demonstrate the multidisciplinary implications of the concept.Because of its comprehensive scope, the volume is useful both as a resource for those interested in contemporary philosophy and theories of language and as a text for courses in such areas as the philosophy of language, critical theory, and the philosophy of knowledge. Originally published as a special issue of ’Critical Inquiry’, the present collection includes two new contributions by Max Black and Nelson Goodman, along with a comprehensive index to the work.
title: On metaphor

abstract: Prepared by nine distinguished philosophers and historians of science, this thoughtful reader represents a cooperative effort to provide an introduction to the philosophy of science focused on cultivating an understanding of both the workings of science and its historical and social context. Selections range from discussions of topics in general methodology to a sampling of foundational problems in various physical, biological, behavioral, and social sciences. Each chapter contains a list of suggested readings and study questions.
title: Introduction to the philosophy of science

abstract: As Aristotle stated, scientific explanation is based on deductive argument–yet, Wesley C. Salmon points out, not all deductive arguments are qualified explanations. The validity of the explanation must itself be examined. ’Four Decades of Scientific Explanation’ provides a comprehensive account of the developments in scientific explanation that transpired in the last four decades of the twentieth century. It continues to stand as the most comprehensive treatment of the writings on the subject during these years.Building on the historic 1948 essay by Carl G. Hempel and Paul Oppenheim, ’Studies in the Logic of Explanation,‚Äù which introduced the deductive-nomological (D-N) model on which most work on scientific explanation was based for the following four decades, Salmon goes beyond this model’s inherent basis of describing empirical knowledge to tells us ‚Äúnot only ’what,’ but also ’why’.‚Äù Salmon examines the predominant models in chronological order and describes their development, refinement, and criticism or rejection.’Four Decades of Scientific Explanation’ underscores the need for a consensus of approach and ongoing evaluations of methodology in scientific explanation, with the goal of providing a better understanding of natural phenomena.
title: Four decades of scientific explanation

abstract: An excellent beginner’s book without making you feel like a dummy or one that leaves you feeling you should never of opened the book. Dr. Shand is truly a needed author for the likes of people like me who have tried to read and understand philosophy and never could read or understand the main concepts of this interesting and challenging field of everyday thoughts. Plus the bonus of him being British. The Brits have a remarkable ability of making something difficult easy to understand. Dr. Shand starts out with the Presocrates and ends with recent Philosphers. Examples of recent Philosophers: Saul Kripke, J.L. Austin, W.V.O. Quine and many more. A beautifully written book for the average person. The book also includes an excellent bibliography with a brief word about each of the books mentioned. The world needs more people and books such as this to kick start our student’s and the average person’s interest in philosophy.
title: Philosophy and philosophers: An introduction to western philosophy, first edition
Matter space and motion

abstract: This volume presents a selection of the most influential recent discussions of the crucial metaphysical questions: what is it for one event to cause another? The subject of causation bears on many topics, such as time, explanation, mental states, the laws of nature, and the philosphy of science.
title: Causation
Ethics

abstract: The 14th edition of ’The Chicago Manual of Style’ has now been superseded by the 15th edition. See below for a link to the new edition. The ISBN of the new 15th edition is 0-226-10403-6.
title: The chicago manual of style: The essential guide for writers, editors, and publishers

abstract: This book is not a conventional introduction to the philosophy of mind, nor is it a contribution to the physicalist/ dualist debate. Instead The Representational Theory of Mind demonstrates that we can construct physicalist theories of important aspects of our mental life. Its aim is to explain and defend a physicalist theory of intelligence in two parts: the first six chapters consist of an exposition, elaboration and defence of human sentience (the functionalist theory of mind), and the second part considers rivals and objections to this theory. Kim Sterelny aims to introduce people to this area of philosophy be exemplifying it, to show that philosophical and empirical investigations can be synthesized to the benefit of both. It is both introduction and argument, explanation and manifesto and succeeds in bridging the widening gap between student primer and contemporary research. Technical vocabulary is explained (and defined in a glossary) while the leading edge of current debates is confronted and assessed. This book has been written for people working in philosophy, psychology and the cognitive sciences.
title: The representational theory of mind: An introduction

abstract: Charles Stevens, a prominent neurobiologist who originally trained as a biophysicist (with George Uhlenbeck and Mark Kac), wrote this book almost by accident. Each summer he found himself reviewing key areas of physics that he had once known and understood well, for use in his present biological research. Since there was no book, he created his own set of notes, which formed the basis for this brief, clear, and self-contained summary of the basic theoretical structures of classical mechanics, electricity and magnetism, quantum mechanics, statistical physics, special relativity, and quantum field theory.’The Six Core Theories of Modern Physics’ can be used by advanced undergraduates or beginning graduate students as a supplement to the standard texts or for an uncluttered, succinct review of the key areas. Professionals in such quantitative sciences as chemistry, engineering, computer science, applied mathematics, and biophysics who need to brush up on the essentials of a particular area will find most of the required background material, including the mathematics.
title: The six core theories of modern physics

abstract: In this extensive inquiry into the sources of modern selfhood, Charles Taylor demonstrates just how rich and precious those resources are. The modern turn to subjectivity, with its attendant rejection of an objective order of reason, has led–it seems to many–to ’mere’ subjectivism at the mildest and to sheer nihilism at the worst. Many critics believe that the modern order has no moral backbone and has proved corrosive to all that might foster human good. Taylor rejects this view. He argues that, properly understood, our modern notion of the self provides a framework that more than compensates for the abandonment of substantive notions of rationality. The major insight of ’Sources of the Self’ is that modern subjectivity, in all its epistemological, aesthetic, and political ramifications, has its roots in ideas of human good. After first arguing that contemporary philosophers have ignored how self and good connect, the author defines the modern identity by describing its genesis. His effort to uncover and map our moral sources leads to novel interpretations of most of the figures and movements in the modern tradition. Taylor shows that the modern turn inward is not disastrous but is in fact the result of our long efforts to define and reach the good. At the heart of this definition he finds what he calls the affirmation of ordinary life, a value which has decisively if not completely replaced an older conception of reason as connected to a hierarchy based on birth and wealth. In telling the story of a revolution whose proponents have been Augustine, Montaigne, Luther, and a host of others, Taylor’s goal is in part to make sure we do not lose sight of their goal and endanger all that has been achieved. ’Sources of the Self’ provides a decisive defense of the modern order and a sharp rebuff to its critics.
title: Sources of the self: The making of the modern identity

abstract: Dual language edition (original Latin as originally printed verso facing authoritative English translation of same page recto).Tranlated by Aloysuis P. Martinich.Edited with an introduction by Isabel Creed Hungerland and George R. Vick.Part of the Janus Series.

Covers textual and linguistic matters; mathematical analyses of Euclid’s ideas; commentators; refutations, supports, extrapolations, reinterpretations and historical notes. Includes 2,500 years of critical commentary. Total in set: 995 figures.

abstract: With that said, The New College-Latin and English Dictionary, is by far the most comprehensive Latin dictionary I have put my hands on. In comparison to the Cassell Dictionaries, The New College Dictionary offers a simple layout packed with as much information as its 663 pgs. can handle. I first began using this particular dictionary the beginner of my third year of latin, with logical grammatical paradigms and a 70,000 word dictionary it is hard to exploit a flaw in this dictionary. Athough it is hard to give an indepth review on a dictionary, the only reassurance I can provide is that this dictionary will definately not disappoint a Latin scholar who is looking to translate classical or middle age Latin as a scholar or hobbyist.
title: The bantam new college latin & english dictionary
Hippocratic writings
Philosophy in the middle ages;: An introduction

abstract: Richard Watson certainly seems like an amiable man, a great asset for your vernissage, your cocktail party, or any other function that merits a lively imagination above actual knowledge. I won’t bore you stiff by addressing every blatant error in this book: it will suffice to say that our Prof. Disney has, single-handedly, come up with an entirely new successor to Prince Frederick-Henry of Orange (1584 - 1647): a certain Henry III. All it takes is a monkey (Descartes would have loved that) with a computer, to google himself to enlightenment: that the good prince Frederick Henry was in fact succeeded by his son William II, who was succeeded by his son, William III, Prince of Orange and King of England, Schotland and Ireland. ’Elementary, my dear Watson’. (And no, Richard: Descartes didn’t meet Huygens in 1630, they first met in 1635, and no, no, Richard: ’Stadhouder’ is not quite the same as ’Commander-in-Chief’, and no, no, no, Richard: Constantijn Huygens served two, not three Stadhouders as first secretary, etc. etc.). All this nonsense in one page (160).
title: Cogito, ergo sum: The life of Rene Descartes

abstract: In the first part of the book, Alberto Coffa traces the roots of logical positivism in a semantic tradition that arose in opposition to Kant’s theory that a priori knowledge is based on pure intuition and the constitutive powers of the mind. In Part II, Coffa chronicles the development of this tradition by members and associates of the Vienna Circle. Much of Coffa’s analysis draws on the unpublished notes and correspondence of many philosophers. The book, however, is not merely a history of the semantic tradition from Kant ’to the Vienna Station.’ Coffa also critically reassesses the role of semantic notions in understanding the ground of a priori knowledge and its relation to empirical knowledge and questions the turn the tradition has taken since Vienna.
title: The semantic tradition from Kant to carnap: To the vienna station
title-short: The semantic tradition from Kant to carnap

abstract: This book, originally published by Capricorn Books in 1968, contains writings by the chief exponents of romanticism and the evolutionary theory in its various applications: Rousseau, Kant, Schiller, Blake, Wordsworth, Goethe, Coleridge, Emerson, Hegel, Marx, Mill, Darwin, Spencer, James, Baudelaire, Schopenhauer, Kierkegaard, Nietzsche, Dostoevsky, and others. Between them, these two movements carried Western thought from the rationalism of the Enlightenment to the existentialism of the 20th century. Suitable for courses in history and literature.
title: Romanticism and evolution

abstract: Written by one of the century’s truly great thinkers, Ludwig Wittgenstein’s ’Philosophical Investigations’ is a remarkable–and surprisingly approachable–collection of insights, statements, and nearly displayed thinking habits of the philosopher’s work on language, symbols, categories, and a host of other topics. Organized into nearly 700 short observations, this book is a treasure trove for anyone who needs to think carefully about objects, categories, and symbols, especially in relation to structured logic applications in computer programming. The short (and sometimes aphoristic) observations in ’Philosophical Investigations’ allow the reader to ponder basic questions on what describes a category, how language works in everyday situations, and how symbols function to represent our world. Originally a series of notes to himself as he lectured on philosophy, the book is a brilliant grab bag of thought and example. Often framed as a question (’How do I recognize that this is red?’), the philosopher provides short answers in a sentence or two, never more than a paragraph. (The second part of the book uses longer answers of several pages to develop its arguments.) An index lets the reader browse on topics of interest–such as language, concept, games, or naming. Any artificial intelligence researcher looking to understand human language will be intrigued by Wittgenstein’s ideas on how symbols and language operate. And for anyone who designs software with objects, this book’s careful attention to thinking about what makes a good category demonstrates rigorous thinking about everyday objects and things. ’Philosophical Investigations’ is at times a strange and often wonderful book that reveals the thought processes of one of history’s finest minds. It exposes the fundamental problems of using language as a means of teaching machines to ’think’ using words. ’–Richard Dragan’ Topics covered: Theory of language and language games, meaning and symbols, concepts and categories, behavior, games (including chess), color, images and perception, grammar and language, sensations, theory of mind and thinking.
title: Philosophical investigations

abstract: In this 1921 opus, Wittgenstein defined the object of philosophy as the logical clarification of thoughts and proposed the solution to most philosophic problems by means of a critical method of linguistic analysis. Beginning with the principles of symbolism, the author applies his theories to traditional philosophy, and more. Introduction by Bertrand Russell.
title: Tractatus logico philosophicus

With lots of quotes on the foundations of epistemology.

abstract: For thousands of years, people have used nature to justify their political, moral, and social judgments. Such appeals to the moral authority of nature are still very much with us today, as heated debates over genetically modified organisms and human cloning testify.The Moral Authority of Nature offers a wide-ranging account of how people have used nature to think about what counts as good, beautiful, just, or valuable. The eighteen essays cover a diverse array of topics, including the connection of cosmic and human orders in ancient Greece, medieval notions of sexual disorder, early modern contexts for categorizing individuals and judging acts as "against nature," race and the origin of humans, ecological economics, and radical feminism. The essays also range widely in time and place, from archaic Greece to early twentieth-century China, medieval Europe to contemporary America.Scholars from a wide variety of fields will welcome The Moral Authority of Nature, which provides the first sustained historical survey of its topic.Contributors: Danielle Allen, Joan Cadden, Lorraine Daston, Fa-ti Fan, Eckhardt Fuchs, Valentin Groebner, Abigail J. Lustig, Gregg Mitman, Michelle Murphy, Katharine Park, Matt Price, Robert N. Proctor, Helmut Puff, Robert J. Richards, Londa Schiebinger, Laura Slatkin, Julia Adeney Thomas, Fernando Vidal

abstract: Before publishing his landmark Meditations in 1641, Rene Descartes sent his manuscript to many leading thinkers to solicit their objections to his arguments. He included these objections, along with his own detailed replies, as part of the first edition. This unusual strategy gave Descartes a chance to address criticisms in advance and to demonstrate his willingness to consider diverse viewpoints—critical in an age when radical ideas could result in condemnation by church and state, or even death.Descartes and his Contemporaries recreates the tumultuous intellectual community of seventeenth-century Europe and provides a detailed, modern analysis of the Meditations in its historical context. The book’s chapters examine the arguments and positions of each of the objectors—Hobbes, Gassendi, Arnauld, Morin, Caterus, Bourdin, and others whose views were compiled by Mersenne. They illuminate Descartes’ relationships to the scholastics and particularly the Jesuits, to Mersenne’s circle with its debates about the natural sciences, to the Epicurean movements of his day, and to the Augustinian tradition. Providing a glimpse of the interactions among leading 17th-century intellectuals as they grappled with major philosophical issues, this book sheds light on how Descartes’ thought developed and was articulated in opposition to the ideas of his contemporaries.

annote: 103: One good reason to also explore the explanatory forms found in Quaestiones Mechanicae and their relationship to Descartes’ physics is that, setting aside his laws of motion and the rules of collision, there is nothing particularly mathematical about Descartes’ mechanistic explanations. Rather he relies heavily on analogies to simple mechanical devices to infer similar mechanical principles at work in the cosmoscosmos at large. Descartes’ even admits to having been inspired by the study of machines in developing his mechanistic explanation of what goes on at the microscopic level of bodies.Hattab’s article makes clear, if not explictly, that discussion regarding the status of mechanics took place in the context of "subalternation"!! Lots of quotes here. Easily found. Talk of "borrowing" principles, "being subordinate", "part of", etc. follow pink underlines.

annote: Naturalisms in different philosophical arenas should be kept distinct, at least on first consideration. Moreover, Naturalism is opposed to a variety of views, some ontological, some epistemological, some semantic, some concerning justifications, etc. Audi offers the following criteria for determining whether a philosophical position in naturalized, and to what extent: a) Scope. How wide is the targe category—the object to be naturalized? (i.e., the normative, the abstract, the supernatural). This category can be naturalized either directly, by elimination, or indirectly, by a reconstructive reduction which preserves a good deal of our discourse about the naturalized category, except that it now lacks those features that had rendered it un-natural. b) Strength. Considerations of strength rest of Modality, Reductivity, and Compositionality. Modality is the nature of the naturalization: is it analytic, a priori, nomic, etc. Reductivity concerns whether the non-natural phenomena are claimed to be identical to natural ones, supervienient on, dependent on, etc. Compositionality: don’t quite get this one “the degree to which a naturalization project takes the target category into physical constituents or, less commonly, into something else supposed to be more natural than the target category”. c) Motivation. Is the motivation ontological, methodological or epistemological? Audi details attempts at naturalizing Metaphysics, Epistemology and Ethics. The last section is interesting (p. 40), where he treats the interrelations between these domains.

annote: The question regarding the seperability of the intellect must be read in relation to the discussion of separability of mental power: so the question is whether there exists a type of being endowed with intellect alone. Discussion about the correlatives argument, separating fields of study. The problem seems to be that De Anima subsumes the soul into the study of nature, while Parts of Animals makes clear that certain parts of the soul, the intellect, is not part of the study of nature. The solution is the “teleological perspective" according to which the study of any thing presupposes the end to which that thing is directed. So with the human animal, a knowledge of its end—intellectual activity—is required for the study of its animal being. These seem initially at odds to me, but Broadie spend some time showing they are not. A large theme of the paper concerns the role of the investigator as having the same nous as the objects of his study, and I don’t understand the importance, which Broadie signifies is large.

annote: On De Generatione et CorrpotioneDe Generatione et Corrpotione. The goal is stated as i) the causes and definition of coming to be and passing away of things which come to be and pass away by nature—all of them alike. ii) what growth and alteration are, and iii) whether alteration differs from coming to be simplicitersimpliciter. Burnyeat’s question is why the discussion focuses on the elements when it is supposed to apply to all those things that are generated. Previous commentators (Joachim) held that Aristotle intendsintends to deal with elements only, but according to Burnyeat this suggests a reduction that is not to be found in Aristotle (Why need forms if generation is reducible to elements?) and flies against the proclamation of the text. Evidence from De SensuDe Sensu and De AnimaDe Anima and PhysicsPhysics show that the same theory of generation is assumed in those locations, and its subject matter is substantial change, not only elemental change. Further evidence is advanced regarding the architectonic nature of Aristotle’s writings, particularly that knowledge of the biological domain comes after and depends upon knowledge of physics, de caelo, de genphysics, de caelo, de gen, and meteorologicameteorologica, thus the theory of the elements should be significant for the whole of Aristotle’s philosophy of nature. The remainder of the essay concern 3 senses of the word foundational: physical foundations, conceptual foundations, and teleological foundations, and the way in which GC is foundational to Aristotle’s enterprise.(1) Physical FoundationsPhysical Foundations. Burnyeat considers the study of the elements foundational in that the elements are the physical components of sublunary life. GC and De CaeloDe Caelo are methodologically unique because they “pincer" Aristotle’s investigation, constituting the top and bottom of his universe. De CaeloDe Caelo is presented in a hypothetical, yet deductively rigorous style, combining necessity and epistemic modesty. This is because knowledge of the heavens is limited, and must consist in deduction from dubitable first principles. GC is methodologically unique in a different way. Here, knowledge of the concept (like coming to be, growth, mixture, etc.) are very well known, so the truth must be sorted out by relentless dialectic". GC also presupposes earlier discussion, particularly the discussion of contant in PhysicsPhysics V. 2, as change occurs through contact.(2) Conceptual Foundations.Conceptual Foundations. In GC Aristotle refers to the topics of the PhysicsPhysics as earlier. In what sense? A logical sense, and the order of proper learning.(3) Teleological Foundation. Burnyeat suggests that the conceptual order of treatises should also indicate that their end is their goal. Understanding life is the goal towards which the rest of the Aristotelian corpus is developed. I didn’t read this section carefully, the discussion boils down to invoking intelligible matter. Read Anderson paper first.

annote: My object is to question a recurrent claim made to the point that Thomas Reid (1710–1796) was hostile to ether theories and that this hostility had its source in his distinctive interpretation of the first of Newton’s “regulae philosophandi". Against this view I will argue that Read did not have any quarrel at all with unobservable or theoretical entities as such, and that his objections against actual theories concerning ether were scientific rather than philosophical, even when based on Newton’s first rule. I argue further that Reid’s insistence on Newton’s rule concerns, not direct observation, but rather the notion of explanation itself.
title: The hypothesis of ether and reid’s interpretation of Newton’s first rule of philosophizing

annote: In all studies during the present century one may detect an underlying asumption that Galileo wrote his DialogueDialogue as an ardent Copernican who allowd that burning conviction to affect his scientific judgment. Drake no longer accept this assumption. Accepting this assumption leads to the opinions of Wallace and McMullin, who portray Galileo as a sophisticated philosopher, which Drake believes he is not. Drake pushed the H-D method throughout, and suggests that Galileo felt no conflict with the church because he saw his own reasoning as merely probably. Also, the key to understanding Galileo’s physics in the second day is to view it purely kinematically. Drake holds that contradictions only arise if Galileo is straddled with impetus or inertia (circular or otherwise) notions. The only conservation principle attributed to him should be conservation of speed. Moreover, Drake holds these interpretations results from viewing Galileo as an overzealous Copernican. I’m not sure if contradictions disappear with kinematics, or how Copernicanism promotes dynamism. Galileo Copernicanism results from his tidal theory, not the other way around.The argument relies on “oddities”oddities associated with the first printing in 1632:The first sentence of the title does not make any reference to the World Systems. It only lists Galileo, the Duke, etc. Only the second full sentence mentions the systems. At the trial, the book was only referred to by the first sentence. Moreover, the book does not promise any astronomical reasons, only physical and philosophical.The preface calls attention to the 1616 regulation of books on Copernicanism, which Galileo had previously battled against.The general statements about the overall purpose of the dialogue are at odds with one another. In the preface, it is to discuss “wonders of heaven and earth”wonders of heaven and earth. In the beginning of the first day, it is the Ptolmeic vs. Copernican system. At the end of the fourth day, it is tides (which are only mentioned before in the middle of the second day, but with a note that this is a subject of much consequence).Nice quote from Riccardi regarding his take on the purpose of the book, citing hypothetical and merely mathematical reasoning. Riccardi edited Galileo’s the preface, which accounts for oddity 2 above. Corpernicanism gets pushed to the front of the preface not because Galileo intended it to, but because discussion of the tides had to be pushed later (since the title was not allowed to be on tides).Drake notes that if Galileo was suspicious at all of possible prohibition of the book, it is unlikely he would have undertaken it (being already 60!). Instead, he obeys the 1616 edict (which was fair to astronomers and did not disallow all use of the copernican hypothesis) and uses reasoning ex suppositioneex suppositione.Simplicio attacks Galileo’s ex supex sup reasoning as a petitio principipetitio principi: basing an explanation of the tides on a supposition which the explanation is supposed to confirm. Moreoever, why aren’t tides observed in air, which, like water, is not rigidly tied to the Earth? Galileo never answers this charge.Drake speculates that this is because Galileo anticipated that the charge would be leveled from philosophic quarters, and he was concerned with convincing the common man, who would not have cared for such subtleties. Drake notes his disagreement with Wallace and McMullin that Galileo paid attention to fine philosophical debates, pinning their misinterpretation on the assumption that Galileo was an overzealous Copernican.As for the nature of Galileo’s physics:
title: Reexamining galileo’s dialogue
Galileo gleaning, v: The earlist version of galileo’s mechanics

annote: More on the idea of discrete impetus theories, focusing on Fabri’s mathematized theory and his response to Galileo. See (Drak75?) for the heart of the historical thesis. The essay concerns the conflict between two thesis: that speeds of fall are proportional to distance, or to time. Drake argues that there was no conflict between these prior to Galileo. The miscontrual is based on a misinterpretation of Albert of Saxony’s version of the speed-distance rule. In fact, there was no precise rule in Albert: “there was an inherent indeterminacy in the imperus theory of free fall which made it impossible to assign a unique time or place in free fall from rest for any one “degree of speed”. The impetus theory was intended to provide a causal explanation of fall. A reconstruction of Galileo’s law of free fall was given by Baliani and Fabri in the mid 1600s, basing it on a “deeper” law. Drake claims that both based their law on Buridan’s impetus theory.
title: Impetus theory and quanta of speed before and after galileo

annote: Why was the mean speed theorem (showing speeds proportional to times) not applied to impetus theory? Instead, impetus theorists adopted the rule that speed was proportional to distances traveled. Drake argues this was not an oversight, but that conceiving of speed as non-continuous means that the continuous mean speed theorem cannot be applied. The argument is based on a reading of Buridan’s impetus theory.Why was the mean speed theorem (showing speeds proportional to times) not applied to impetus theory? Instead, impetus theorists adopted the rule that speed was proportional to distances traveled. Drake argues this was not an oversight, but that conceiving of speed as non-continuous means that the continuous mean speed theorem cannot be applied. The argument is based on a reading of Buridan’s impetus theory.Put another way, there was an incompatibility between impetus theories and a continuous view of speed. Drake claims his interpretation explains why several of Galileo’s successors (notably Descartes) rejected the idea that a body from rest passes though all degrees of speed, and an event in 1543.Medieval writers made a distinction between entities that could be present all at once, and those that had to be “spread out”spread out.The concept on an instant was certainly known before Galileo. Aristotle used it in regutation of motion in a void, holding that such motion would be instantaneous and thus impossible. Similar problem with instants occured elsewhere. In the case of the punctum reflexionispunctum reflexionis, if stoping and starting occured in one instant, then there would be a contradition (a body being both at rest and in motion).Drake notes that the latin for degree (gradus) connoted gradations, i.e., discontinuous quantities.Jean Buridan coined the term impetus for the left-over force (vis derelictavis derelicta) left in a projectile after it left the thrower. He held that this force was “permanent”permanent, and this is usually taken to indicate a prescient inertia theory, where the inherent impetus can only be removed through external impediments (like the medium). However, Drake would like to urge that this “permanent”permanent should be understood as “present”present (this relies on his earlier discussion of permeo – i.e., permeating, not permanent). He cites Clagett’s translation of Buridan.

annote: The domains of physics and mathematics were defined in terms of their subject matters: physics is concerned with those things that change and have an independent existence, mathematics with those things that do not change and have no independent existence.The force of this doctrine lies in the fact that it has a grounding in Aristotelian metaphysics and in the theory of the syllogism, and a highly developed and closely co-ordinate systematic physics, in close agreement with observation and common sense, is construced on the basis of it (p. 97)NB: he does not mention epistemology in the Aristotelian context. Unlike Galileo, who wanted to show that mathematical treatment of physical problems is possible, Descartes wanted to unifyunify mathematics and physics, Gaukroger wants to focus on this notion.
title: Descartes’ project for a mathematical physics

annote: Concerns the “unintended consequences” of the mathematization of nature. Contains a nice quote from Barrow about the co-extension of mathematics and physics in the preface. The unintended consequences are: 1) social: the use of mathematics had the effect of excluding actors from the legitimate participation in the discourses on natural philosophy; 2) epistemological: the use of math in dynamics (as distinct from its use in kinematics) had the effect of transforming the very meaning of the term “explanation” as it was used by philosophers in the 17th cent.; 3) ontological: mathematization has lef to the vanishing of substances. Section (2) is interesting, with many good quotes from the Jesuit Castel
title: What did mathematics do to physics?

abstract: Before publishing his landmark Meditations in 1641, Rene Descartes sent his manuscript to many leading thinkers to solicit their objections to his arguments. He included these objections, along with his own detailed replies, as part of the first edition. This unusual strategy gave Descartes a chance to address criticisms in advance and to demonstrate his willingness to consider diverse viewpoints—critical in an age when radical ideas could result in condemnation by church and state, or even death.Descartes and his Contemporaries recreates the tumultuous intellectual community of seventeenth-century Europe and provides a detailed, modern analysis of the Meditations in its historical context. The book’s chapters examine the arguments and positions of each of the objectors—Hobbes, Gassendi, Arnauld, Morin, Caterus, Bourdin, and others whose views were compiled by Mersenne. They illuminate Descartes’ relationships to the scholastics and particularly the Jesuits, to Mersenne’s circle with its debates about the natural sciences, to the Epicurean movements of his day, and to the Augustinian tradition. Providing a glimpse of the interactions among leading 17th-century intellectuals as they grappled with major philosophical issues, this book sheds light on how Descartes’ thought developed and was articulated in opposition to the ideas of his contemporaries.

annote: Leibniz brings together the conception of Bacon and Descartes regarding the unity of the sciences. In Bacon, “the limits [on the unity of science] are not fixed, however, by the theory of knowledge [as in Aristotle, scholastics, etc.!] but by religion, which sharply separates itslef from science, and having done so, declares what is to be reserved to tis own jusidiction” (p. 27). This conception has it the all science, by which he means any product of rational thought, must have as its purview the natural world. Metaphysics, therefore, which is a science, must also be about the natural world, it must be “a part of Physic”. McRae continues to examine ethics, politics; in characteristic style, he is either all over the place, or I just don’t get him.... Any science, however, is merely a reflection of the natural order. Since nature is unified (story about God, creation, Laws, etc.), so must be the sciences. In De Augmentis Scientiarum, Bacon offers the image of a tree (Bk I, ch. xiii, in Works VIII, 449), whose trunk is Philosophia Prima and is composed of axioms which are “the footsteps of nature”. Bacon parts with the Aristotelian conception of the separation of sciences according to their subject matter (i.e., genus) by holding that it is necessary for science to have “intercourse” with one another and that “the particulars and instances of one science” supply information for the “framing or correcting of the axioms of another scinece in their very truth and notion” (from Valerius Terminus, ch. I). Logic is also able to critique the principles of any science. Sciences differ from one another only in generality, since all are based on induction from particularlys: they differ only in their level of generality. For McRae the contrast between Bacon and Descartes is that Bacon grounds the unity of science in Nature, while Descartes grounds it in the Mind. First, Descartes opposes the division of the science according to subject matter and hold that this is only the case for practical arts, whose methods are appropriate to their subject matter. It is by training on certain subject that the mind becomes accustomed to solving problems in other subjects. The most fruitful of concentrations is mathematics. McRae notes that Descartes distinguishes science from the “Mechanical Arts”. What’s up here? Continues in the same way, not very informative, historically awful, with no sustained focus on any single work: great example of cherry-picking historiography.

annote: "This major intellectual biography illuminates the personal and historical events of Descartes’s life, from his birth and early years in France to his death in Sweden, his burial, and the fate of his remains." “Concerned not only with historical events but also with the development of Descartes’s personality, Rodis-Lewis speculates on the effect childhood impressions may have had on his philosophy and scientific theories. She considers in detail his friendships, particularly with Isaac Beeckman and Marin Mersenne. Primarily on the basis of his private correspondence, Rodis-Lewis gives a thorough and balanced discussion of his personality. The Descartes she depicts is by turns generous and unforgiving, arrogant and open-minded, loyal in his friendships but eager for the isolation his work required." “Drawing on Descartes’s writings and his public and private correspondence, she corrects the errors of earlier biographies and clarifies many obscure episodes in the philosopher’s life."–BOOK JACKET.
title: Descartes: His life and thought
The system of locke and Newton

annote: His recounting of the emergence of the epistemological problematic in philosophy follows the historiographical traditions of Gilson and Randal. Rorty writes:Descartes is dimly envisaging a similarity between the “simple natures”simple natures which we know in mathematical physics... and the colors themselves. Colors, in his official, Galilean, metaphysical view, are secondary qualities waiting upon analysis into simples, but epistemologically they seem, like pain, to have the same sort of primitive inescapability as the simple natures themselves. He could not make the analogy explicit without setting his foot on the road toward Lockean empiricism. But neither could he give it up without falling back into the old Aristotelian distinction between the sensitive and the intellectual souls. This would have brought back all the pre-Galilean metaphysics which he wanted to avoid, not to mention a hylomorphic empistemology impossibly difficult to reconcile with the explanatory power of Galilean mechanics. (p.57)Even better:The hylomorphic epistemology which thought of grasping universals as instancing in one’s intellect what the fron instanced in its flesh was, thanks to the rise of mathematical physics, being replaced by a law-event framework which explained froghood as possible a merely “nominal”nominal essence. So the notion of reason as a faculty of grasping universals was not available for use in a premise proving the distinctness of the mind from the body. The notion which would define what could “have a distinct exitence from the body”have a distinct exitence from the body was one which would draw a line between the cramps in one’s stomach and the associated feeling in one’s mind (p.62)andBut precisely this notion of one big substance [i.e., extension] was what was needed to provide a “philosophical foundation”philosophical foundation of Galilean mechanics while heaping scorn on traditional hylomorphic explanations. (p.65)In this context, Rorty cites Burtt, who in Chap IV of Metaphysical FoundationsMetaphysical Foundations holds that the criteria of reality for Descartes is not permanence but the possibility of mathematical handling.

annote:
As usual, erudiate article. Nice discussion of Huygens, although he casts his claims in modern phrasing, and I believe is missing part of the discussion, especially in the discussion of Huygens’ concept of mass. I believe casting these claims in the language of proportionality may make Stein thesis—that Huygens’ had a full-blown concept of weight—less strong. First segment of the paper focuses on Huygnes, his law of conservation of motion, the treatment of impact and centrifugal force. Very nice exposition on all three. A short discussion of the difference between Huygens’ and Newton, refering to the early optical correspondece. The focus there is whether explanatory categories are “primary” in the causal sense (i.e., “original”), or not. This is the sequeway to Locke, with the claim that in the first edition of the Essay, this causal definition of primary qualities is more pronounced than a later resemblance-based definition. The remainder of the article is a comparison of Locke and Newton. The main points are:
1. ‘The qualities Locke calls primary and original constitute a fixed list; it is clear that Newton’s usage is more flexible–like the properties he discovers of light.
2. the primary qualities of Locke correspond, in principle, to a subset of “the simple Ideas we receive from Sensation and Reflection”. The properties called primary by Newton are, on the contrary, of the class that Locke calls secondary Qualities, mediately perceivable. ***p. 31ff. is a discussion of the nature of certain Knowledge, Stein makes the claim that although Locke denies the very possibility of a scientific natural philosophy, all the exception to this are passsages in which Locke refers explicitly to Newton. He supplies examples.
3. The third difference is between two different concpetion of what is required for a systematic science from an epistemological pov. There is a somewhat circumlocutious discussion, hitting on the main points, but worth returning to.
4. There is a difference in metaphysics itself (rather than its epistemic ground). Stein discussion of De Grav here, concerning substance and its creation, and the claim that Newton totally rejects the notion of substance, while Locke merely holds it to be unintelligible, and a return to some of the epistemic issues.
5. Concerning first principles, Newton does not fold, like Aristotle, Huygens, etc. that first principles are determined in a process that precedes science, but are part of the scientific investigation itself.

annote: Focuses on the division of sciences by Henry of Langenstein (d.1397). Contains several references to commentaries on Metaphyscis. Henry divides the “real sciences" into natural and abstractive. The natural sciences (also, physics) divide into natural philosophy and medicine and it is these “that by investigating takes under consideration the causes of things in their effects and the effects from their causes, and it derives its name from “physics” in Greek, which is “nature” in Latin" (p.253). The fact that Henry places physics and mathematics on two separate branching of the arbor and that he does not stress the role mathematics plays in physics puts him squarely in teh tradition of thirteenth-century Aristotelian’s such as Albertus Magnus and Thomas Aquinas and at odds with the Oxford Platonic tradition of Robert Grosseteste, Robert Kilwardby, and Roger Bacon. A list of middle sciences that includes science of weights. p.254 of this essay is useful. NB: the middle sciences are not defined metaphysically, but by the statement that they apply mathematics to “particular problems"
title: A late medieval arbor scientiarum

annote: B837 .S86 1985 146 B837. Introduces a distinction between “hard” and “soft” naturalism; hard naturalism is reductive. Also uses Hume on induction to introduce the idea that certain of our beliefs are closed off to reason and are arrived at simply because of the things we are, simply because of our nature (think induction and habits). He ends up with a position that is similar to McDowell’s, urging us to admit that, by nature, we must accept items into our mental landscape that a strict reductionism to the physical sciences would disallow. It is different from McDowell, I think, because he still believes that such items are closed off from reason, whereas McDowell wants to expand the scope of reason to reach them. This is from a 15 minute reading.
title: Skepticism and naturalism : Some varieties

annote: The argument is against Platonic and H-D versions of Galileo’s method. Against the Platonists, it has become clear through the work of Tom Settle, and then Drake, etc. that Galileo had actually run experiments with fairly reasonable results. The argument against H-Dism is more complicated. Certainly, the intuition behind the method was available to Galileo. However, the method was not thought to yield certain result by Galileo’s contemporaries (and Galileo does not seem to use terms like demonstration, proof, etc. any differently than his contemporaries). Nevertheless, Galileo claimed that his method yielded certainty. Wallace third possibility is that the method used was Ex Suppositione.Ex Suppositione. Curiously, the terms was not used synonymously with ex hypothesiex hypothesi, although it is a direct translation of the greek phrase. The latter phrase was used in a positivistic manner, to refer to proposition meant to “save the phenomena”save the phenomena.Methodology of DemonstrationMethodology of DemonstrationMethodology of Demonstration The use of ex supex sup stems from Aquinas, who dealing with the problem of establishing necessary causes in a world of change, suggests that necessary connection can be discovered only by demonstrations ex supex sup. The suppositionesuppositione is an effect that is caused in generalin general, i.e., through what is thought to be proper functioning. From this effect, the causes can be known, although the effect as such may not always obtain in nature.Early NotebooksEarly NotebooksEarly Notebooks Galileo’s notebooks, as well as notes taken by his students show that he was aware of the Aristotelian method, and particularly concerned with the Posterior AnalyticsPosterior Analytics, etc. Wallace pins the argument on Galileo’s use of Clavius’ commentary of The SphereThe Sphere in taught courses. Clavius was a champion of apodictic proof and argued that astronomy was concerned with finding true motions, not saving the phenomena. Nice quote here from a letter to Vinta in 1610 concerning Galileo’s life projects: he mentions the dialogo and discorsi. Anyway, Galileo distinguishes between the positivist and realist version of ex sup.ex sup. The terms itself is used twice in the discorsidiscorsi and twice more in letters concerning it.

annote: The terms causacausa and visvis were used to designate both external and internal causes in the $13^thth$ and $14^thth$ centuries. The latter use resurfaced in the $16^thth$ century, perhaps because of the translation in 1539 and 1558 for Philoponus. The distinction is crucial, since Philopanus explicitly introduces the term form, calling nature a quaedam visquaedam vis (instead of only a principium et causaprincipium et causa), which is diffused throughout bodies. Galileo treats “nature”nature in this way, but does not attack the metaphysics of how it actually causes motion. Wallace focuses on the writing of Muzio Vitelleschi, A Jesuit and the Collegio Remano, who attacked this question. A more detailed analysis is contained in (Galil&Wall77?).In general, the essay does not discuss the anima munidianima munidi tradition or platonic influences. However, Wallace takes this to be important first because it gets codified in the Coimbra commentaries and second because it is almost identical with the metaphysics endorsed by Mertonian and ParisiensesParisienses in the $14^thth$ century. Moreover, Galileo attended Vitelleschi’s lectures and took notes.Nature as a Cause or ForceNature as a Cause or ForceNature as a Cause or ForceAlthough Vitelleschi is worried that force as an inherent cause may have pantheistic implications, he uses the concept extensively: nature is an internal principle, propensity, virtue, quality, or force for their proper motion. Is this to be considered an efficient cause?Motion is natural if it proceeds from the inclination of a body. It is violent if it is imposed from the outside and the body does not contribute any force to it; moreover, the external cause must be contrary to the body’s internal inclination. However, the inherent cause of motion can be perceived passively alone. It must be initiated by another internal principle, which is the body’s substantial form. This is the efficient form, although it is not a proper one, but one that acts by emenation.in the very process of its motion the element is further in potency [there is the potency of the substantial form itself and the potency of removing impediments] to its particular terminus or natural place, and this last potency is activated by its motive force or quality as an instrument, but in this case the active principle from which the motive quality flows is the substantial form of the element.(p.403)Aristotle did not mention this type of cause in his discussion of motion because it is not a proper efficient cause and because he was only interested in causality from without.There are 3 causal sequences in the fall of a body: 1) when impediment are removed, the element is moved by its substantial form as an agent. 2) the entire element (not just the form) moves the surrounding medium, and it the efficient cause of this motion. 3) as the medium moves, it removes more impediments.Motive ForcesMotive ForcesMotive Forces Motive qualities or forces are either natural or impressed. Are the natural qualities primary, or do they arrise from other qualities of bodies? To this question Vit has a three-fold answer... Another question is whether these are distinct between, say, earth and water, which both move downwards. Vit holds that they are, both because of differing termini and differing speed. The story here is interesting, although a little complex. A third question is what happens to the power (and the motion itself) when the bodies are in their proper places. Vit holds the property does not go away, but remains in “first act”first act.
title: Causes and forces in sixteenth century physics

annote: Hylomorphism is the view that the relation of the soul to body bears some illuminating resemblance to the relation of form to matter. Discussion begins with the bronze sphere, the same example that is used to motivate many discussion of the subaltern sciences! The first difficulty is what count as “matter” of a living thing. It cannot simply be “body”, given the tangle of difficulties about a body’s being potentially alive presented in Met. Zeta and De Anima. Similarly, it cannot be “flesh and bone”. Williams suggests that we ought to think of “Body” as the matter for a “living body” of a “living animal”. Problems with this account is that “Body” looks remarkably like ’body’ and that mental functions are assigned to a conglomerate of body and soul. The conjunction of this leads to a very deflationary view, which suggests that Kallias is indentified not with his “Body”, but his “body”, and this is precisely the point which Aristotle stresses is not the case. Implication regarding fields of study is given on p. 195. Williams continues to list ways in which hylomorphism is unstatsfactory, wavering between dualism and materialism.

annote: B1875 .E87 1993 The problem is why the principle of virtual speeds does not appear in the Principles, although Descartes used it elsewhere. Evidence of Descartes use through letters with Huygens and Mersenne. A discussion of what “mechanics" and “physics" meant, and then an explanation of the principles tree passage. The bottom line: Descartes’ uses “mechanics” in the historically appropriate way, as a discipline that has been relegated to the mathematicians, but it part of natural philosophy in general. This is why he makes the distinction, also, since it deals with weight, which is a terrestrial phenomena, the law of virtual speeds is not primary, but must be deduced from deeper physical laws.

annote: The conversations with Burman (and previously held common wisdom) have it that the Principles are a synthetic presentation of the Meditation, which are analytic in nature. Descartes’ distinction between analytic/synthetic are offered in the Second Replies. Gueroult interprets this distinction as corresponding to the one in the Regulae between the order of knowing and the order of being. However, Gueroult interpretation does not make sense of the texts. The Principles and the Meditation are alike in overall order: both begin with doubt, move to god, and continue to the natural world.Edwin Curley begins offers a different interpretation, starting with the idea that we can learn most about Descartes’ use of synthesis by looking comparing the Second Replies and the Principles. Certain similarities can be found: use of definitions, formal principles, and the lack of heuristic, false-start arguments that are used in the Meditations.But neither of these approaches establish that Descartes really saw the Principles as a synthetic work! In fact, Descartes could have refered to the Principles as synthetic on many occasions, but he did not. Garber lists such occasions. Ultimately, Garber concludes that the analytic/synthetic distinction does not matter for understanding the Principles. The argument is convincing, although not air-tight.
title: A point of order: Analysis, synthesis and Descartes’ principles

annote: A description of the“method" of the rules, which is the method descartes discusses, although briefly, in the Discourse. The method involves a reductive and a constructive step. Analysis of the anaclastic line and the rainbox example. However, Descartes stops using the method explicitly after 1637. Garber disagrees with those who claim that the Meditations in an instance of Descartes’ old method. But why did Descartes abandon the method?Garber gives two reasons. First, since the method was based on the interconnectedness of knowledge, the project of building a systematic philosophy becomes more and more important. Second, the method is built on intuition and deduction. But how do we know that these lead to truth? The method itself must be based in something deeper, in a metaphysics.I think that Garber ignores that failures of the method. The method is also based on a representational theory of mind, and on the grasp of simple natures that are easily intuited and imagined. Once Descartes discovers that we can no longer imagine all the concepts that may be useful for us (such as a negative root), he’s got to rethink the theory of mind, and the theory of mind needs to take with it the whole of method. If anything of the method remains, it is only in very broad terms, of breaking problems into smaller chunks, etc. It is the very detailed method of the Regulae.

title: Descartes and method in 1637

abstract: Before publishing his landmark Meditations in 1641, Rene Descartes sent his manuscript to many leading thinkers to solicit their objections to his arguments. He included these objections, along with his own detailed replies, as part of the first edition. This unusual strategy gave Descartes a chance to address criticisms in advance and to demonstrate his willingness to consider diverse viewpoints—critical in an age when radical ideas could result in condemnation by church and state, or even death.Descartes and his Contemporaries recreates the tumultuous intellectual community of seventeenth-century Europe and provides a detailed, modern analysis of the Meditations in its historical context. The book’s chapters examine the arguments and positions of each of the objectors—Hobbes, Gassendi, Arnauld, Morin, Caterus, Bourdin, and others whose views were compiled by Mersenne. They illuminate Descartes’ relationships to the scholastics and particularly the Jesuits, to Mersenne’s circle with its debates about the natural sciences, to the Epicurean movements of his day, and to the Augustinian tradition. Providing a glimpse of the interactions among leading 17th-century intellectuals as they grappled with major philosophical issues, this book sheds light on how Descartes’ thought developed and was articulated in opposition to the ideas of his contemporaries.
annote: Morin was Descartes’ intended target in the geometrical portion of the second replies. This is because Morin published a proof of the existence of god in a geometrical style in 1636.Morin was a conservative, but of an open-minded sort. Lots of details regarding Morin’s book and the exchanges with DescartesPunchline: Descartes was displeased with synthesis as a method of metaphysics. He wants to show that Morin is misguided by constructing his own synthetical method, but with a curious set of postulates.Garber’s ultimate point is that analysis/synthesis is less relevant to understanding Descartes philosophical method.

annote: Half of the essay is devoted to the issue of scientific change, drawing on Kuhn, although arguing against him, and Sellars. The basic notion is that scientific development includes the expansion of the explanatory power of theories. Galileo is then used as an example.In regards to Galileo, Pitt wants to claim that Galileo destroyed the priority of scientia propter quidscientia propter quid over scientia quiascientia quia by insisting on the descriptive power of the mathematical tool. Several quotes from the Dialogues are given regarding the superiority of mathematics, and the relation between human and divine understanding of mathematical truths. The essay goes under the assumption thatGaileo has made a sharp break with the long-standing geometric-mechanical tradition. For in insisting that the mathematics yields true knowledge, Galileo argues that mathematics has a more powerful use than merely to construct interesting models which serve to save the phenomena. (p.188)As Wallace (as Lennox) have argued, this is a mis-representation of Aristotelianism, although some Renaissance Aristotelianisms may fit the bill. The shift in Jesuit thinking and the death of Clavius has a great role to play here, I’m sure.The argument supporting the quote above rests on Galileo’s statements regarding realism about the mathematical structure of the world. Pitt’s main point is thatGalileo allow that a description of the structure of the universe is not an account of the causal principles governing the motion of the various components of this system. But it can be an explanation if exploted from the perspective of realism. (p.191)A slogan of Pitt’s article: the explanation is the demonstration (p.192). His case relies on mathematical demonstrations lacking “the causal principles traditionally deemed necessary for scientific knowledge as scientia propeter quid.scientia propeter quid. I’m not sure what these are. Regardless, the claim is that he is free to ignore them because he is a realist about mathematics.
